lessons.title: 1. Hello, World!
lessons.description: The classic first step in programming. Your goal is to print the exact text "Hello, World!" to the console. Use `System.out.println()` to achieve this.
lessons.tutorial:
In Java, the console is a text output window. To print text to it, we use a built-in command from the System library.

The command is System.out.println(). The ln part means "line," so it prints the text and then moves to the next line.

Example:

// This line will print "Welcome to Java!" to the console.
System.out.println("Welcome to Java!");

// This will print a number. Numbers don't need quotes.
System.out.println(123);

For this lesson, you need to print the specific phrase "Hello, World!".

lessons.title: 2. Variables & Data Types
lessons.description: Variables are containers for storing data. Declare an integer variable named `myNumber`, assign it the value `42`, and then print the variable to the console.
lessons.tutorial:
In Java, a variable is like a labeled box where you can store information. You must first declare it by giving it a data type and a name.

  • int: for whole numbers (e.g., 5, -10, 42).
  • String: for text (e.g., "Hello, World!").
  • double: for decimal numbers (e.g., 3.14).
  • boolean: for true or false values.

Example:

// 1. Declare a variable 'age' of type 'int'
int age;

// 2. Assign the value 25 to it
age = 25;

// You can also declare and assign in one line (which is common):
int score = 100;

// 3. Print the value stored in the variable (notice no quotes)
System.out.println(score); // This will print 100

In this lesson, create an int variable named myNumber, give it the value 42, and print it.

lessons.title: 3. Arithmetic & Assignment
lessons.description: Update the balance by adding the deposit and subtracting the withdrawal using compound assignment, then print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
Use arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /) for calculations. Compound assignment like += and -= updates a variable without rewriting its name.

Example:

int total = 10;
total += 5;  // same as total = total + 5
total -= 2;
total++;    // adds one (same as total += 1)
System.out.println(total);

This shorthand is essential for counters such as i++ that you'll rely on in loops.

lessons.title: 4. Increment & Decrement
lessons.description: Increase the counter to 3 using the ++ operator, then print it.
lessons.tutorial:
The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators add or subtract 1. They are shorthand for counter = counter + 1 and counter = counter - 1.

Example:

int lives = 3;
lives--;   // now 2
int score = 0;
score++;  // now 1

You'll use i++ constantly when writing loop counters.

lessons.title: 5. Comparison Operators
lessons.description: Compare the score to the passingScore to create a boolean named isPassing, then print it.
lessons.tutorial:
Comparison operators (>, >=, <, <=, ==, !=) evaluate to boolean results.

Example:

int temperature = 72;
boolean isWarm = temperature >= 70;
System.out.println(isWarm); // true

These boolean expressions power if statements and loop conditions.

lessons.title: 6. While Loops
lessons.description: A `while` loop executes a block of code as long as a specified condition is true. Create a loop that prints numbers from 1 to 5, each on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
A while loop is used to repeat a block of code as long as a condition is met. It's useful when you don't know exactly how many times you need to loop.

Crucially, you must ensure the condition eventually becomes false, otherwise you'll create an infinite loop!

Example:

int countdown = 3;

while (countdown > 0) {
    System.out.println(countdown);
    countdown--; // This is essential to avoid an infinite loop!
}

System.out.println("Blast off!");

For this lesson, initialize a counter and use a while loop to print numbers 1 through 5. Don't forget to increment your counter inside the loop!

lessons.title: 7. For Loops
lessons.description: A `for` loop is ideal when you know exactly how many times you want to loop. Use a for loop to print the numbers from 0 to 4, each on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
A for loop provides a concise way to write a loop structure. It consists of three parts, separated by semicolons:

  1. Initialization: Executed once at the beginning (e.g., int i = 0).
  2. Condition: Evaluated before each loop iteration. If it's false, the loop stops (e.g., i < 5).
  3. Increment/Decrement: Executed at the end of each iteration (e.g., i++).

Example:

// This loop will print "Iteration 0" through "Iteration 4"
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
    System.out.println("Iteration " + i);
}

Your task is to create a for loop that prints the value of the counter i on each iteration, from 0 up to (but not including) 5.

lessons.title: 8. Introduction to Arrays
lessons.description: An array is a collection of similar types of data. Create an array of integers, store some numbers in it, and then print the second element from the array.
lessons.tutorial:
An array is a container object that holds a fixed number of values of a single type. The length of an array is established when the array is created.

Array elements are accessed by their index, which starts at 0. So, the first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and so on.

Example:

// Declare and initialize an array of Strings
String[] fruits = {"Apple", "Banana", "Cherry"};

// Access and print the first element (index 0)
System.out.println(fruits[0]); // Prints "Apple"

// Access and print the third element (index 2)
System.out.println(fruits[2]); // Prints "Cherry"

Your task is to create an integer array and print the element at index 1, which is the second value in the list.

lessons.title: 9. Intro to Classes & Objects
lessons.description: Java is an Object-Oriented language. A `class` is a blueprint for creating `objects`. Create a simple `Dog` class with a `bark()` method, then create an object of that class and call its method.
lessons.tutorial:
A class is a template for creating objects. It defines an object's properties (fields) and behaviors (methods).

An object is an instance of a class. You can create many objects from a single class blueprint.

Example:

// The blueprint for a Car
class Car {
    // A behavior (method) of the Car
    public void startEngine() {
        System.out.println("Engine started!");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Create an object (an instance) from the Car class
        Car myCar = new Car();
        
        // Call a method on the object
        myCar.startEngine(); // Prints "Engine started!"
    }
}

lessons.title: 10. Advanced Conditionals (Else If)
lessons.description: Check multiple conditions using `if`, `else if`, and `else`. Based on the `score` variable, print 'Excellent' for scores > 90, 'Good' for scores > 75, and 'Needs Improvement' for all others.
lessons.tutorial:
The if-else if-else statement is perfect for when you have multiple conditions to check in sequence. Java checks them from top to bottom and runs the code for the first one that is true.

Example:

int number = 0;

if (number > 0) {
    System.out.println("The number is positive.");
} else if (number < 0) {
    System.out.println("The number is negative.");
} else {
    System.out.println("The number is zero.");
}

Notice how only one of the blocks can ever run. The final else is a catch-all if none of the previous conditions were met.

lessons.title: 11. Else-If Chains with &&
lessons.description: Decide a student outcome using if/else-if/else and the && operator. Score >= 90 prints "Honors"; score >= 75 with bonus prints "Pass"; everything else prints "Retake".
lessons.tutorial:
Check conditions in priority order. Combine requirements with && so a branch runs only when both parts are true.

Example:

int age = 17;
boolean hasPermit = true;
if (age >= 18) {
    System.out.println("Full License");
} else if (age >= 16 && hasPermit) {
    System.out.println("Learner Permit");
} else {
    System.out.println("Not eligible");
}

lessons.title: 12. Logical Operators
lessons.description: Combine conditions using logical operators. Use the `&&` (AND) operator to check if a user is both `loggedIn` and an `isAdmin`. To pass, change `isAdmin` to `true` and print 'Admin Access Granted'.
lessons.tutorial:
Logical operators let you create more complex conditions:

  • && (AND): True only if both conditions are true.
  • || (OR): True if at least one condition is true.
  • ! (NOT): Inverts the boolean value (true becomes false, false becomes true).

Example:

int age = 25;
boolean hasLicense = true;

if (age >= 18 && hasLicense) {
    System.out.println("You are eligible to drive.");
}

For this lesson, you'll need to write an if statement that checks if both loggedIn and isAdmin are true. To make the condition pass, you will also need to change the value of isAdmin from false to true.

lessons.title: 13. Creating Methods
lessons.description: Write a reusable block of code called a method. Create a method named `greetUser` that takes a `String` name as a parameter and prints 'Hello, [name]!'. Call this method from `main` with your own name.
lessons.tutorial:
Methods (also called functions in other languages) help you organize code and avoid repetition. You define it once and can call it many times.

A method signature has a few parts: visibility (public), other modifiers (static), return type (void if it returns nothing), the method name, and parameters in parentheses.

Example:

public class Main {

    // A method that takes two integers and prints their sum
    public static void add(int a, int b) {
        System.out.println(a + b);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Call the add method with different arguments
        add(5, 3);   // Prints 8
        add(10, 20); // Prints 30
    }
}

lessons.title: 14. Methods with Return Values
lessons.description: Methods can compute and return a value. Create a method `add` that takes two integers, returns their sum, and then print the returned result from the `main` method.
lessons.tutorial:
So far, our methods have used void, meaning they don't return any information. By changing void to a data type (like int or String), we can make the method send a value back to where it was called.

The return keyword is used to specify what value to send back. When return is executed, the method stops immediately.

Example:

public class Main {

    // This method takes a number and returns that number doubled.
    public static int doubleValue(int number) {
        return number * 2;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // We call the method and store its return value in a variable.
        int answer = doubleValue(5);

        // Now we can use the result.
        System.out.println(answer); // Prints 10
    }
}

Your task is to create an add method that returns the sum of two numbers.

lessons.title: 15. Array Length & Bounds
lessons.description: Use .length to read the first and last elements of an array and print the count.
lessons.tutorial:
Arrays know their size via the length field. Valid indexes run from 0 up to length - 1.

Example:

int[] nums = {2, 4, 6};
System.out.println(nums[0]);  // 2
System.out.println(nums[nums.length - 1]); // 6
System.out.println(nums.length); // 3

lessons.title: 16. Looping Through Arrays
lessons.description: Combine loops and arrays to process each item in a collection. Use a `for` loop to iterate through an array of strings and print each name on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
A very common task is to perform an action on every item in an array. A for loop is perfect for this.

You can get the number of items in an array using the .length property. This is extremely useful for setting the loop's condition, ensuring it runs exactly the right number of times.

Example:

int[] scores = {98, 87, 100, 91};

// The loop runs as long as 'i' is less than the array's length.
for (int i = 0; i < scores.length; i++) {
    // We use the loop variable 'i' as the index to get each element.
    System.out.println("Score " + i + ": " + scores[i]);
}

Your goal is to loop through the names array and print each element using System.out.println().

lessons.title: 17. String Concatenation
lessons.description: Combine strings using the `+` operator. Create two string variables and combine them with a space in between to form a sentence, then print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
In Java, the + operator does double duty. When used with numbers, it performs addition. When used with strings, it performs concatenation, which means it joins them together.

You can combine variables and string literals (text in quotes) to build up complex strings.

Example:

String user = "Alex";
int level = 5;

// We can combine strings and other data types.
// Java automatically converts the number 'level' to a string.
String message = "Welcome, " + user + "! You are on level " + level + ".";

System.out.println(message); // Prints "Welcome, Alex! You are on level 5."

For this lesson, combine the two provided strings. Don't forget to add a space " " in between them!

lessons.title: 18. Constructors
lessons.description: A constructor is a special method that is called when an object is created. Add a constructor to the `Car` class that accepts a `String` for the car's color and prints a message.
lessons.expectedOutput: A new blue car has been created.
lessons.tutorial:
A constructor in Java is a special method used to initialize objects. It is called at the time of object creation. It must have the same name as the class and does not have a return type.

Constructors are great for setting up the initial state of an object.

Example:

class Dog {
    String name;

    // This is the constructor for the Dog class.
    public Dog(String dogName) {
        // 'this.name' refers to the instance variable.
        // 'dogName' refers to the parameter.
        this.name = dogName;
        System.out.println("Dog created with name: " + this.name);
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // The constructor is called when we use 'new'.
        Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido"); // Prints "Dog created with name: Fido"
    }
}

lessons.title: 19. this for Fields in Constructors
lessons.description: Use this to assign constructor parameters to fields, then call an instance method that references the field.
lessons.tutorial:
this disambiguates between fields and parameters with the same name. It's common to store constructor arguments on the instance this way.

Example:

class Player {
    private String name;
    public Player(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }
}

lessons.title: 20. Static vs Instance Fields
lessons.description: Keep a static count of created sessions while storing each session's user name separately.
lessons.tutorial:
Use static for data shared by every instance (class-level state) and instance fields for per-object details. Access static members through the class name.

Example:

class Counter {
    static int total = 0;
    Counter() { total++; }
}

lessons.title: 21. Enhanced For Loop
lessons.description: Java provides a simpler `for-each` loop to iterate over arrays or collections. Use an enhanced for loop to print each fruit from the `fruits` array.
lessons.tutorial:
The enhanced for loop (or for-each loop) is a more readable and concise way to iterate through all the elements of an array or collection, without needing an index variable (like i).

The syntax is for (Type variableName : arrayName). In each iteration, the loop automatically assigns the next element from the array to your variable.

Example:

int[] numbers = {10, 20, 30};

// For each 'number' of type 'int' in the 'numbers' array...
for (int number : numbers) {
    // ...print it out.
    System.out.println(number);
}

This is often preferred over a standard for loop when you just need to access each element in order and don't need the index.

lessons.title: 22. User Input (Scanner)
lessons.description: Real programs need to interact with users. Use the `Scanner` class to get input. The simulation will provide the input "World". Your task is to read it and print "Hello, World".
lessons.tutorial:
To get input from a user in the console, Java provides the Scanner class. It's part of Java's utility library, so you must first import it at the top of your file with import java.util.Scanner;.

You then create a Scanner object, telling it to read from the standard input stream, System.in.

Example:

import java.util.Scanner;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner myScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.println("What is your name?");

        // The program will pause here and wait for the user to type.
        String name = myScanner.nextLine(); 

        System.out.println("Nice to meet you, " + name);
    }
}

For this lesson, the simulator will automatically type "World" for you. Your job is to read that input using scanner.nextLine() and use it to construct the final output.

lessons.title: 23. Switch Statement
lessons.description: Use a `switch` statement to handle different cases for a character variable. Based on the `grade`, set the `comment` variable to the correct string.
lessons.tutorial:
The switch statement is a cleaner alternative to a long chain of if-else if-else statements when you need to compare one variable against several possible constant values.

The break keyword is crucial. If you forget it, the code will "fall through" and execute the code in the next case as well, which is usually not what you want.

Example:

int day = 4;
String dayString;

switch (day) {
    case 1:  dayString = "Monday";
             break;
    case 2:  dayString = "Tuesday";
             break;
    case 3:  dayString = "Wednesday";
             break;
    // ... and so on
    default: dayString = "Invalid day";
             break;
}
System.out.println(dayString); // Prints "Wednesday" if day was 3

Your task is to build a switch statement for the character variable grade. Note that you need to declare the comment variable before the switch, but you will assign its value inside the different cases.

lessons.title: 24. Modifying Array Elements
lessons.description: Arrays are mutable, meaning you can change their contents. Access an element by its index and assign a new value to it.
lessons.tutorial:
Because arrays are mutable (changeable), you can easily update their values. You use the same index syntax you used to read a value, but now you use it on the left side of an assignment operator (=).

Example:

int[] numbers = {1, 2, 99};

// Print the original third element
System.out.println(numbers[2]); // Prints 99

// Change the value at index 2
numbers[2] = 3;

// Print the new third element
System.out.println(numbers[2]); // Prints 3

Your task is to change the first element of the heroes array to "Black Panther" and then print that first element to the console.

lessons.title: 25. Array Loop Accumulators
lessons.description: Use a for loop to compute both the total and maximum value from the scores array, then print total followed by max.
lessons.tutorial:
Loops often keep state across iterations?running totals, min/max tracking, or flags. Initialize before the loop, update inside, and use the results afterward.

Example:

int min = numbers[0];
for (int n : numbers) {
    if (n < min) {
        min = n;
    }
}

lessons.title: 26. Sum of Array Elements
lessons.description: A common task is to iterate through an array to calculate a value. Use a for-each loop to calculate the sum of all numbers in an array.
lessons.tutorial:
This lesson combines several concepts: arrays, loops, and variable modification. The goal is to create an "accumulator" variable (sum) that starts at 0. Then, you loop through each element of the array and add its value to your accumulator.

Example:

int[] scores = {5, 10, 15};
int total = 0;

for (int score : scores) {
    total += score; // This is a shorthand for total = total + score;
}

System.out.println("The total is: " + total); // Prints "The total is: 30"

Your task is to do the same for the numbers array and print out the final calculated sum.

lessons.title: 27. Finding the Maximum Value
lessons.description: Iterate through an array to find the largest value. This is a classic algorithm that combines loops and conditional logic.
lessons.tutorial:
To find the maximum value in an array, you need a variable to keep track of the largest number found so far. A good strategy is to initialize this variable with the very first value from the array.

Then, you loop through the rest of the array. For each number, you compare it to your "max so far" variable. If the current number is larger, you update your max variable with the current number's value. By the end of the loop, your variable will hold the largest value in the entire array.

Example:

int[] temps = {72, 85, 68, 91, 78};
int highestTemp = temps[0]; // Start with 72

for (int temp : temps) {
    if (temp > highestTemp) {
        highestTemp = temp; // Update if we find a warmer day
    }
}

System.out.println(highestTemp); // Prints 91

lessons.title: 28. Finding the Average
lessons.description: Calculate the average of a list of numbers. This requires summing the elements and then performing floating-point division.
lessons.tutorial:
Calculating an average involves two steps: finding the sum of all elements, and then dividing by the number of elements.

A key concept in Java is integer division versus floating-point (double) division. If you divide an integer by an integer, Java will truncate the result (e.g., 5 / 2 is 2). To get a precise decimal answer, at least one of the numbers in the division must be a double. We can do this by making our sum variable a double from the start.

Example:

int a = 7;
int b = 2;
System.out.println(a / b); // Prints 3 (integer division)

double c = 7.0;
System.out.println(c / b); // Prints 3.5 (floating-point division)

lessons.title: 29. Inheritance (extends)
lessons.description: Inheritance allows a new class (subclass) to inherit properties and methods from an existing class (superclass). Create a `Dog` class that inherits from `Animal`.
lessons.expectedOutput:
This animal eats food.
Woof!
This animal eats food.
Meow!
lessons.tutorial:
Inheritance is a core principle of Object-Oriented Programming. It allows us to create a new class that is a modified version of an existing class. The new class (the subclass) inherits the fields and methods of the existing class (the superclass).

We use the extends keyword to do this. This promotes code reuse and creates a logical hierarchy.

Example:

// Superclass
class Vehicle {
    public void drive() {
        System.out.println("Driving a vehicle.");
    }
}

// Subclass
class Car extends Vehicle {
    public void honk() {
        System.out.println("Beep beep!");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Car myCar = new Car();
        myCar.drive(); // Inherited from Vehicle
        myCar.honk();  // Defined in Car
    }
}

lessons.title: 30. Override toString()
lessons.description: Override toString() so printing a Student shows "Student: <name> (<level>)".
lessons.tutorial:
Override toString() to give your objects meaningful printouts, which helps debugging and logging.

Example:

@Override
public String toString() {
    return "Point(" + x + ", " + y + ")";
}

lessons.title: 31. Polymorphism & Overriding
lessons.description: Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass. This is often achieved by overriding methods.
lessons.tutorial:
Polymorphism means "many forms". In Java, it means you can perform a single action in different ways. A common way to use it is when a superclass reference variable is used to refer to a subclass object.

Method overriding is when a subclass provides a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass. The @Override annotation is used to indicate this; it's not required but is good practice as it helps the compiler catch errors.

Example:

class Shape {
    public void draw() {
        System.out.println("Drawing a shape");
    }
}

class Circle extends Shape {
    @Override
    public void draw() {
        System.out.println("Drawing a circle");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Shape myShape = new Circle(); // Polymorphism!
        myShape.draw(); // Calls the Circle's draw() method
    }
}

lessons.title: 32. ArrayList
lessons.description: An `ArrayList` is a resizable array, part of the Java Collections Framework. It's more flexible than a standard array.
lessons.tutorial:
While arrays are useful, their size is fixed once created. The ArrayList class provides a way to have a dynamic, resizable list of objects.

You must import it from java.util.ArrayList. Here are some common methods:

  • add(element): Adds an element to the end of the list.
  • get(index): Returns the element at the specified index.
  • size(): Returns the number of elements in the list.
  • remove(index): Removes the element at the specified index.
  • set(index, element): Replaces the element at the specified index with a new one.

ArrayList is a resizable list. Use add() to append and get() to access by index.

Example:

java.util.List list = new java.util.ArrayList<>();
list.add(1); list.add(2); list.add(3);
System.out.println(list);

lessons.title: 33. Interfaces
lessons.description: An interface is a completely abstract type that is used to group related methods with empty bodies. A class can `implement` an interface, promising to provide the code for its methods.
lessons.expectedOutput:
The pig says: wee wee
Zzz
lessons.tutorial:
An interface is like a blueprint for a class. It can only contain abstract methods (methods without a body) and constants. A class can implement one or more interfaces.

This is Java's way of achieving full abstraction and is a key part of designing large, flexible applications. It defines a "contract" that a class must follow if it implements the interface.

Example:

interface Drivable {
    public void startEngine();
}

class Car implements Drivable {
    public void startEngine() {
        System.out.println("Car engine started.");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Car myCar = new Car();
        myCar.startEngine();
    }
}

lessons.title: 34. Exception Handling (try-catch)
lessons.description: Robust programs must handle potential errors gracefully. Use a `try-catch` block to prevent a crash when trying to divide by zero.
lessons.tutorial:
An exception is an event that disrupts the normal flow of a program. Java's exception handling mechanism allows you to manage these errors without crashing the application.

The try block contains the code that might throw an exception. The catch block contains the code that is executed if an exception of a specific type occurs in the try block.

Example:

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] numbers = {1, 2, 3};
        try {
            // This line will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
            System.out.println(numbers[10]);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            // This block runs instead of the program crashing
            System.out.println("Something went wrong.");
        }
    }
}

lessons.title: 35. HashMap
lessons.description: A `HashMap` stores items in "key/value" pairs. Create a HashMap to store capital cities, add a few pairs, and then retrieve a value using its key.
lessons.tutorial:
A HashMap is a powerful data structure for storing key-value pairs, similar to a dictionary. Each value is associated with a unique key. It's incredibly fast for looking up values when you know the key.

Like ArrayList, you must import it from java.util.HashMap. Common methods include:

  • put(key, value): Adds a key-value pair.
  • get(key): Returns the value associated with the key.
  • remove(key): Removes the key-value pair.
  • size(): Returns the number of pairs.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 36. Mini Assert Utility
lessons.description: Implement a very small assertEquals helper that throws IllegalArgumentException on mismatch, then prints PASS.
lessons.tutorial:
Testing frameworks throw when expectations fail. A tiny helper that compares values and raises on mismatch mirrors JUnit's behavior.

Example:

static void assertTrue(boolean condition) {
    if (!condition) throw new IllegalArgumentException("not true");
}

lessons.title: 37. Read Env Default
lessons.description: Return an environment variable when set, otherwise a fallback value.
lessons.tutorial:
Environment variables are often optional during local development, so code should fall back to safe defaults.

Example:

Map<String, String> env = System.getenv();
String url = env.getOrDefault("DATABASE_URL", "sqlite:///app.db");
System.out.println(url);

Cache System.getenv() in a local map so tests can stub it and you only look up the key once.

lessons.title: 38. String Methods
lessons.description: The `String` class has many useful methods. Use `length()`, `toUpperCase()`, and `substring()` to manipulate a string and print the results.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Length: 10
Uppercase: HELLO JAVA
Substring: Java
lessons.tutorial:
Strings in Java are objects, and they come with many built-in methods for common operations.

  • length(): Returns the number of characters in the string.
  • toUpperCase() / toLowerCase(): Returns a new string in the specified case.
  • substring(startIndex): Returns a new string from the start index to the end.
  • substring(startIndex, endIndex): Returns a new string from the start index up to (but not including) the end index.

Example:

String greeting = "Welcome!";
System.out.println(greeting.length()); // Prints 8
System.out.println(greeting.substring(0, 3)); // Prints "Wel"

lessons.title: 39. Math Class
lessons.description: The `Math` class contains methods for performing basic numeric operations. Use `Math.max()` and `Math.sqrt()` to find the larger of two numbers and the square root of another.
lessons.tutorial:
The Math class provides a collection of static methods for mathematical calculations. You don't need to create an object of the Math class; you can call its methods directly.

  • Math.max(a, b): Returns the largest of two values.
  • Math.min(a, b): Returns the smallest of two values.
  • Math.sqrt(n): Returns the square root of a number.
  • Math.random(): Returns a random double between 0.0 and 1.0.
  • Math.abs(n): Returns the absolute (non-negative) value.

Classes bundle data and behavior. Create an instance with new and call its methods.

Example:

class Dog {
  void bark() { System.out.println("Woof!"); }
}
new Dog().bark();

lessons.title: 40. StringBuilder
lessons.description: When you need to build a string by appending many parts, `StringBuilder` is more efficient than regular string concatenation. Use it to build a sentence.
lessons.tutorial:
Every time you use the + operator to concatenate strings, Java creates a new string object in memory. This can be inefficient if you do it many times in a loop. StringBuilder is a mutable object that allows you to modify a sequence of characters without creating new objects for each change.

Use append() to add to the string. When you are finished, call toString() to get the final String object.

String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

Example:

String s = "Java";
System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
System.out.println(s.length());

lessons.title: 41. The `super` Keyword
lessons.description: The `super` keyword refers to the superclass. It can be used to call the superclass's constructor or methods. Call the `Animal` constructor from the `Dog` constructor.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Animal constructor called for: Fido
Dog constructor called.
lessons.tutorial:
The super keyword is used inside a subclass to refer to its immediate parent (superclass). There are two main uses:

  1. super(arguments): To call a constructor of the superclass. If used, it must be the very first statement in the subclass constructor.
  2. super.methodName(): To call a method of the superclass, which is useful if the subclass has overridden that method but you still need the original behavior.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 42. Method Overloading
lessons.description: Method overloading allows you to define multiple methods with the same name in the same class, as long as they have different parameters. Create two `add` methods: one for integers and one for doubles.
lessons.tutorial:
Method Overloading increases the readability of the program. It allows you to have multiple methods with the same name as long as their parameter lists are different (either by the number of parameters, the type of parameters, or both).

Java determines which version of the method to call based on the arguments you provide.

Example:

public void display(int a) {
    System.out.println("Got an Integer: " + a);
}

public void display(String s) {
    System.out.println("Got a String: " + s);
}

display(100); // Calls the first method
display("Hello"); // Calls the second method

lessons.title: 43. Abstract Classes
lessons.description: An abstract class cannot be instantiated and can contain abstract methods (without a body). Create an abstract `Shape` class and a `Circle` subclass that implements its abstract method.
lessons.tutorial:
An abstract class is a restricted class that cannot be used to create objects. It serves as a base for subclasses. It can have both abstract and non-abstract (regular) methods.

An abstract method is a method that is declared without an implementation. Any subclass of an abstract class must either implement all of the superclass's abstract methods or be declared abstract itself.

This provides a middle ground between a regular class and an interface.

Classes bundle data and behavior. Create an instance with new and call its methods.

Example:

class Dog {
  void bark() { System.out.println("Woof!"); }
}
new Dog().bark();

lessons.title: 44. Type Casting
lessons.description: Type casting is when you assign a value of one primitive data type to another type. Perform both widening (automatic) and narrowing (manual) casting.
lessons.tutorial:
Type casting is used to convert variables from one data type to another.

  • Widening Casting: Happens automatically when passing a smaller size type to a larger size type (e.g., int to double). This is safe as there is no data loss.
  • Narrowing Casting: Must be done manually by placing the type in parentheses in front of the value (e.g., (int)). This can lead to data loss, as you are fitting a larger type into a smaller one. For example, casting a double to an int will truncate the decimal part.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 45. Ternary Operator
lessons.description: The ternary operator is a shorthand for an if-else statement. Use it to assign a value to the `result` string based on a condition.
lessons.tutorial:
The ternary operator provides a concise way to write simple conditional assignments. Its syntax is:

variable = (condition) ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse;

Example:

// Using if-else
int x = 10;
String message;
if (x > 5) {
    message = "x is greater than 5";
} else {
    message = "x is not greater than 5";
}

// Using ternary operator (equivalent)
String message2 = (x > 5) ? "x is greater than 5" : "x is not greater than 5";

lessons.title: 46. Do-While Loop
lessons.description: A `do-while` loop is a variant of the while loop which executes the code block once before checking the condition. Use it to print a countdown that includes 0.
lessons.tutorial:
The do-while loop is similar to a while loop, but with one key difference: the condition is checked after the loop body is executed. This guarantees that the loop will run at least once, regardless of whether the condition is true or false.

Example:

int count = 5;

do {
    System.out.println("This will print at least once.");
} while (count < 3); // Condition is false, but loop ran once.

lessons.title: 47. Primitive vs Reference & Autoboxing
lessons.description: Autobox an int into a list, then compare two Integer objects created with valueOf to show equals vs ==.
lessons.tutorial:
Collections hold objects, so primitives auto-convert to their wrapper classes (autoboxing). Two wrapper objects can be equal in value yet occupy different references, so .equals() is the safe comparison.

Example:

Integer a = Integer.valueOf(256);
Integer b = Integer.valueOf(256);
System.out.println(a.equals(b)); // true
System.out.println(a == b);      // false

lessons.title: 48. Wrapper Classes
lessons.description: Wrapper classes provide a way to use primitive data types (like `int`) as objects. Create an `Integer` object and use one of its methods.
lessons.tutorial:
Java has two categories of data types: primitive types and reference types (objects). Sometimes you need to treat a primitive like an object, for example, when using it with collections like ArrayList. Wrapper classes solve this problem.

Each primitive has a corresponding wrapper class:

  • int -> Integer
  • double -> Double
  • char -> Character
  • boolean -> Boolean

The process of converting a primitive to a wrapper object is called autoboxing, and the reverse is called unboxing. Java often does this automatically for you.

Classes bundle data and behavior. Create an instance with new and call its methods.

Example:

class Dog {
  void bark() { System.out.println("Woof!"); }
}
new Dog().bark();

lessons.title: 49. Recursion
lessons.description: Recursion is the technique of making a function call itself. Create a recursive function to calculate the sum of all numbers up to n.
lessons.tutorial:
Recursion is a powerful but tricky concept where a method calls itself to solve a problem. It breaks a complex problem into smaller, identical subproblems.

Every recursive function must have two parts:

  1. A base case: A condition that stops the recursion. Without it, you'll get an infinite loop and a StackOverflowError.
  2. A recursive step: The part of the function that calls itself, usually with a modified argument that brings it closer to the base case.

For this problem, summing numbers up to 5 (5+4+3+2+1) can be thought of as 5 + sum(4), and sum(4) is 4 + sum(3), and so on, until you reach the base case of sum(0).

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 50. 2D Arrays
lessons.description: A 2D array is like a grid or a table, an array of arrays. Create a 2D array and access an element from a specific row and column.
lessons.tutorial:
A 2D array is an array where each element is itself another array. It's useful for representing data in a grid-like structure, such as a tic-tac-toe board or a spreadsheet.

You declare it with two sets of square brackets (e.g., int[][]). To access an element, you provide two indices: the first for the row and the second for the column.

Example:

String[][] board = {
    {"X", "O", "X"},
    {"O", "X", "O"},
    {"X", "O", "X"}
};

// Access the middle element (row 1, column 1)
System.out.println(board[1][1]); // Prints "X"

lessons.title: 51. Looping Through 2D Arrays
lessons.description: To iterate over all elements in a 2D array, you need nested loops: one for the rows and one for the columns.
lessons.tutorial:
To process every element in a 2D array, a common pattern is to use a "nested loop" a loop inside another loop.

The outer loop iterates through each of the main arrays (the rows). The inner loop then iterates through all the elements within that specific row-array (the columns).

Example with for-each loops:

String[][] data = {{"A", "B"}, {"C", "D"}};

for (String[] row : data) {
    for (String element : row) {
        System.out.print(element + " "); // Prints "A B C D "
    }
}

lessons.title: 52. The `final` Keyword
lessons.description: The `final` keyword is used to make a variable a constant, meaning its value cannot be changed. Try to change a final variable to see the error, then fix it by removing the attempt to change it.
lessons.tutorial:
The final keyword is a non-access modifier used for classes, methods, and variables. It has different meanings depending on the context:

  • final variable: Creates a constant. Its value cannot be changed after it has been assigned. By convention, constant names are written in all uppercase letters.
  • final method: Cannot be overridden by a subclass.
  • final class: Cannot be extended (inherited from) by another class.

This lesson focuses on final variables. Attempting to reassign a final variable will result in a compile-time error.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 53. Enums
lessons.description: An enum is a special "class" that represents a group of constants. Define an enum for difficulty levels and use it in a switch statement.
lessons.tutorial:
An enum (short for enumeration) is a special data type that enables for a variable to be a set of predefined constants. The variable must be equal to one of the values that have been predefined for it.

Enums are useful when you have a value that you know is one of a small, fixed set of possibilities, such as days of the week, compass directions, or states in a game. They make code more readable and prevent errors from using invalid values.

Example:

enum Direction {
    NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, WEST
}

Direction myDir = Direction.NORTH;

if (myDir == Direction.NORTH) {
    System.out.println("Heading North!");
}

lessons.title: 54. Access Modifiers (private)
lessons.description: Access modifiers control the visibility of classes, fields, and methods. Use the `private` keyword to encapsulate data and provide public getter/setter methods.
lessons.tutorial:
Java has four access modifiers:

  • public: The code is accessible for all classes.
  • private: The code is only accessible within the declared class.
  • protected: The code is accessible in the same package and subclasses.
  • default (no keyword): The code is only accessible in the same package.

The private modifier is central to the concept of encapsulation. It hides sensitive data from the outside world. To access or modify private data, you provide public "getter" and "setter" methods.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 55. The `continue` Keyword
lessons.description: The `continue` statement breaks one iteration (in the loop), if a specified condition occurs, and continues with the next iteration in the loop. Use it to print only the odd numbers.
lessons.tutorial:
While break exits a loop entirely, continue just skips the current iteration. When the continue statement is executed, the program immediately jumps to the loop's next iteration, bypassing any remaining code in the current iteration.

Example:

// Don't print the number 5
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    if (i == 5) {
        continue; // Skip the rest of the loop body when i is 5
    }
    System.out.println(i);
}

In this lesson, you'll use the modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers and skip them with continue.

lessons.title: 56. Iterating through a HashMap
lessons.description: You can loop through the keys, values, or key-value pairs of a HashMap. Use a for-each loop to print all the keys in the map.
lessons.tutorial:
There are several ways to loop through a HashMap:

  • keySet(): Returns a set of all the keys. You can iterate through this set and use get() to retrieve each value.
  • values(): Returns a collection of all the values. Use this if you don't need the keys.
  • entrySet(): Returns a set of all key-value pairs (as Map.Entry objects). This is the most efficient method if you need both the key and the value in each iteration.

Example using entrySet():

for (Map.Entry entry : capitalCities.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println("Key: " + entry.getKey() + ", Value: " + entry.getValue());
}

lessons.title: 57. The `this` Keyword
lessons.description: The `this` keyword refers to the current object instance. It is commonly used to resolve ambiguity between instance variables and parameters.
lessons.tutorial:
The this keyword is a reference to the current object the object whose method or constructor is being called. It can be used to:

  • Disambiguate between instance variables and parameters when they have the same name (the most common use).
  • Call another constructor in the same class (e.g., this(arguments)).
  • Pass the current object as an argument in a method call.

When a parameter has the same name as an instance variable, the parameter "shadows" the instance variable. Using this.variableName ensures you are referring to the instance variable.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 58. Reading Numbers with Scanner
lessons.description: The `Scanner` class can read specific data types, not just strings. Use `nextInt()` to read an integer from the user and perform a calculation.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Enter your age:
In ten years, you will be 35.
lessons.tutorial:
Besides nextLine(), the Scanner class provides methods to read specific data types directly:

  • nextInt()
  • nextDouble()
  • nextBoolean()
  • next() (reads the next word, not the whole line)

Using these methods can be more convenient than reading a line as a string and then converting it manually. The simulation for this lesson will provide the number "25" as input.

Read input from the console with java.util.Scanner. Close scanners in real programs to free resources.

Example:

import java.util.Scanner;
Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
String name = scanner.nextLine();
System.out.println("Hello, " + name);

lessons.title: 59. String Comparison
lessons.description: When comparing strings for equality, you should use the `.equals()` method, not the `==` operator. The `==` operator checks if two references point to the same object, while `.equals()` checks if the string contents are the same.
lessons.tutorial:
This is a very common point of confusion for new Java programmers. For primitive types (like int, boolean), the == operator works as expected, comparing their values.

However, for objects (like String), == checks if the two variables refer to the exact same object in memory. The .equals() method, on the other hand, is defined in the class to provide a meaningful comparison of the objects' actual contents.

Rule of thumb: Always use .equals() to compare strings for equality.

String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

Example:

String s = "Java";
System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
System.out.println(s.length());

lessons.title: 60. The `finally` Block
lessons.description: The `finally` block in a try-catch statement always executes, regardless of whether an exception was thrown or not. It is used to run important cleanup code.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Inside the try block.
Inside the finally block. Cleanup complete.
lessons.tutorial:
The try-catch-finally structure provides robust error handling. The flow is as follows:

  1. The try block is executed.
  2. If an exception occurs, the corresponding catch block is executed.
  3. The finally block is always executed, whether an exception happened or not. This makes it the perfect place for cleanup code, like closing files or network connections, to ensure resources are released properly.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 61. The `instanceof` Operator
lessons.description: The `instanceof` operator checks whether an object is an instance of a specific class or an interface. Use it to determine the true type of an object.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Is it a Dog? true
Is it a Cat? false
Is it an Animal? true
lessons.tutorial:
The instanceof operator is a type comparison operator that returns true if the object on the left side is an instance of the class on the right side. It also returns true if the object is an instance of a subclass of the class on the right.

This is particularly useful in polymorphism when you have a variable of a superclass type that could be holding an object of any of its subclasses, and you need to perform a specific action based on its actual type.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 62. Course Review
lessons.description: Combine everything you have learned. Create a `Student` class, manage a list of students with an `ArrayList`, and calculate their average score.
lessons.tutorial:
Congratulations on reaching the final review lesson! This challenge combines many of the core concepts you've learned:

  • Classes and Objects: The Student class with a constructor and private fields.
  • Encapsulation: Using a getter method (getScore) to access private data.
  • ArrayList: To hold a dynamic list of Student objects.
  • Loops: A for-each loop to iterate through the list.
  • Variables and Calculations: Summing the scores and calculating the average.

Solving this demonstrates a solid grasp of Java fundamentals. Well done!

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

lessons.title: 63. Spring-Style Controller Method
lessons.description: Create a dummy @GetMapping annotation and use it on a controller method that returns "Hello, World!".
lessons.tutorial:
Spring MVC uses annotations such as @GetMapping to map HTTP routes to controller methods. Defining a no-op annotation lets you practice the syntax without pulling in Spring dependencies.

Example:

@interface PostMapping { String value(); }
class Api {
    @PostMapping("/submit")
    public String submit() { return "OK"; }
}

lessons.title: 64. SpringApplication Runner Stub
lessons.description: Create a SpringApplication-like helper that prints which class is booting.
lessons.tutorial:
Spring Boot apps start via SpringApplication.run. A stubbed version lets you practice the pattern without pulling in dependencies.

Example:

class SpringApplication {
    static void run(Class clazz, String[] args) {
        System.out.printf("Booting %s%n", clazz.getSimpleName());
    }
}

This stub replicates the logging handshake while staying dependency-free.

lessons.title: 65. Spring Boot Mini Project Plan
lessons.description: List the files needed for a minimal Spring Boot REST API and print each filename with its responsibility.
lessons.expectedOutput:
src/main/java/com/example/Application.java -> bootstraps Spring app
src/main/java/com/example/web/ProductController.java -> REST endpoints
src/main/resources/application.properties -> configuration
build.gradle -> dependencies & plugins
lessons.tutorial:
Sketching the project tree clarifies the entry point, web layer, config, and build file you will need before writing code.

Example:

for (var entry : files) {
    System.out.println(entry.getKey() + " -> " + entry.getValue());
}

Mapping each path to a responsibility lets reviewers confirm you covered every layer.

lessons.title: 66. Spring Boot Skeleton Files
lessons.description: Print starter contents for Application and ProductController so learners can immediately run a minimal API.
lessons.initialCode:
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String application = String.join("
",
            "package com.example;",
            "",
            "import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;",
            "import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;",
            "",
            "@SpringBootApplication",
            "public class Application {",
            "    public static void main(String[] args) {",
            "        SpringApplication.run(Application.class, args);",
            "    }",
            "}"
        );
        String controller = String.join("
",
            "package com.example.web;",
            "",
            "import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.GetMapping;",
            "import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RestController;",
            "",
            "@RestController",
            "public class ProductController {",
            "    @GetMapping("/products")",
            "    public String list() {",
            "        return "[]";",
            "    }",
            "}"
        );

        // Print file -> snippet mapping
    }
}
lessons.tutorial:
Provide the starter Application class and REST controller so the plan becomes runnable.

Example:

System.out.println("src/main/java/com/example/Application.java ->");
System.out.println(application);
System.out.println("src/main/java/com/example/web/ProductController.java ->");
System.out.println(controller);

Print the file headers followed by the snippets so teammates can paste them verbatim.

lessons.title: 67. Spring Boot Run Checklist
lessons.description: Print Gradle commands to build and run the Spring Boot app plus the curl call to verify the endpoint.
lessons.tutorial:
Capture the exact commands to boot the service and smoke-test the REST endpoint.

Example:

System.out.println("./gradlew bootRun");
System.out.println("curl http://localhost:8080/products");

Include the curl so ops can validate the new build from the same checklist.

lessons.title: 68. Capstone: Deployment Checklist
lessons.description: Outline the release steps for the Spring Boot service: merge, cherry-pick, run tests, build the jar.
lessons.expectedOutput:
1. git checkout main
2. git merge feature/order-summary
3. git cherry-pick fix-null-order
4. ./gradlew test
5. ./gradlew bootJar
lessons.tutorial:
Capstones capture the release runbook so teammates can execute it without missing critical Git or build steps.

Example:

for (int i = 0; i < tasks.length; i++) {
    System.out.printf("%d. %s%n", i + 1, tasks[i]);
}

Leading with the step number keeps asynchronous reviewers on the same page.

lessons.title: 69. Deploy Spring Boot JAR
lessons.description: Print the commands to run the shaded jar with environment variables for port and profile.
lessons.initialCode:
String jar = "build/libs/inventory-service-1.0.0.jar";

// Print export SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE, export SERVER_PORT, and java -jar command
lessons.expectedOutput:
export SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod
export SERVER_PORT=8080
java -jar build/libs/inventory-service-1.0.0.jar
lessons.tutorial:
Running the jar directly is the simplest deployment option. Set the profile and port so ops tooling can override them.

Example:

System.out.println("export SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod");
System.out.println("export SERVER_PORT=8080");
System.out.println("java -jar " + jar);

Group the exports above the java command so the runtime picks them up.

lessons.title: 70. Capstone: Smoke Tests
lessons.description: Run Gradle smoke tests and curl health check after deploying the jar.
lessons.tutorial:
Post-deploy smoke tests guard against regressions. Automate them (Gradle + curl) and fail the release if either step breaks.

Example:

for (String cmd : cmds) {
    System.out.println(cmd);
}

Keep the list tight so on-call engineers can run the same checks manually.

lessons.title: 71. Collections Warm-Up with Generics
lessons.description: Create a typed list and set, add names (including a duplicate), then print their sizes.
lessons.tutorial:
Generics keep collections type-safe: List<String> guarantees every element is a String. Converting to a Set is a quick way to deduplicate.

Example:

List numbers = new ArrayList<>();
numbers.add(1);
numbers.add(1);
Set unique = new HashSet<>(numbers);
System.out.println(unique.size()); // 1

lessons.title: 72. Streams: map
lessons.description: Use a stream with a lambda to double each number and print each on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
The `map` operation transforms each element of a stream. It applies a function to each element and returns a new stream of the results.

Example:

import java.util.List;
List names = List.of("alice", "bob");
names.stream()
     .map(String::toUpperCase)
     .forEach(System.out::println); // ALICE, BOB printed on new lines

lessons.title: 73. Streams: filter
lessons.description: Filter even numbers from 0..6 and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
The `filter` operation selects elements from a stream that match a given condition (a `Predicate`).

Example:

import java.util.List;
List nums = List.of(1, 2, 3, 4);
nums.stream()
    .filter(n -> n % 2 == 0)
    .forEach(System.out::println); // 2, 4 printed on new lines

lessons.title: 74. Sort by Length
lessons.description: Sort strings by length ascending and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
You can sort collections using a `Comparator`. `Comparator.comparingInt` is a helper for sorting by an integer property, like string length.

Example:

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Comparator;
List words = List.of("fig", "apple", "pear");
words.stream()
     .sorted(Comparator.comparingInt(String::length))
     .forEach(System.out::println); // fig, pear, apple on new lines

lessons.title: 75. Comparator on Objects
lessons.description: Sort objects by a field using Comparator.comparing.
lessons.tutorial:
`Comparator.comparing` extracts a sort key from an object. You provide a lambda that takes an object and returns the property to sort by.

Example:

import java.util.*;
class Person { String name; Person(String n) { name=n; } }
List people = List.of(new Person("Bob"), new Person("Alice"));
people.stream().sorted(Comparator.comparing(p -> p.name))
      .forEach(p -> System.out.println(p.name)); // Alice, Bob

lessons.title: 76. Optional.map
lessons.description: Uppercase a value inside Optional and print it if present.
lessons.tutorial:
`Optional.map` applies a function to the value inside an Optional, if it is present, and returns a new Optional with the result.

Example:

import java.util.Optional;
Optional opt = Optional.of("text");
opt.map(String::toUpperCase).ifPresent(System.out::println); // TEXT

lessons.title: 77. Generic Box<T>
lessons.description: Create a generic Box class and print its value.
lessons.tutorial:
Generics allow you to define classes and methods that are parameterized over types. A `Box` can hold any type `T`.

Example:

class Box { private T t; public void set(T t) { this.t=t; } public T get() { return t; } }
Box intBox = new Box<>();
intBox.set(10);
System.out.println(intBox.get()); // 10

lessons.title: 78. Bounded Wildcards
lessons.description: Sum a list of Numbers using an upper-bounded wildcard.
lessons.tutorial:
Upper-bounded wildcards (`? extends Type`) are used to increase flexibility. A `List` can hold a list of Integers or a list of Doubles.

Example:

import java.util.List;
public static double sum(List list) {
    return list.stream().mapToDouble(Number::doubleValue).sum();
}
System.out.println(sum(List.of(1, 2.5))); // 3.5

lessons.title: 79. Method References
lessons.description: Use method references to map and print.
lessons.tutorial:
Method references are a shorthand syntax for a lambda expression that executes just ONE method. They make code more readable.

Example:

import java.util.List;
List list = List.of("a", "b");
list.stream().map(String::toUpperCase).forEach(System.out::println); // A, B

lessons.title: 80. Reverse Sort
lessons.description: Sort numbers in descending order and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
`Comparator.reverseOrder()` returns a comparator that imposes the reverse of the natural ordering.

Example:

import java.util.*;
List nums = List.of(1, 3, 2);
nums.stream().sorted(Comparator.reverseOrder()).forEach(System.out::println); // 3, 2, 1

lessons.title: 81. Enum + switch
lessons.description: Switch on an enum and print a label.
lessons.tutorial:
Enums work very well with `switch` statements, providing compile-time checking that all cases are handled.

Example:

enum Level { EASY, HARD }
Level level = Level.EASY;
switch (level) {
    case EASY -> System.out.println("Easy mode");
    case HARD -> System.out.println("Hard mode");
}

lessons.title: 82. Record Basics
lessons.description: Use a record to model a point and print x+y.
lessons.tutorial:
Records (Java 16+) provide a compact syntax for declaring classes which are transparent holders for immutable data.

Example:

record Point(int x, int y) {}
Point p = new Point(1, 2);
System.out.println(p.x()); // 1

lessons.title: 83. Streams: reduce
lessons.description: Use reduce to sum numbers.
lessons.tutorial:
The `reduce` operation combines all elements of a stream into a single result.

Example:

import java.util.List;
int sum = List.of(1, 2, 3).stream().reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b);
System.out.println(sum); // 6

lessons.title: 84. Collectors.joining
lessons.description: Join strings with commas using Collectors.joining.
lessons.tutorial:
`Collectors.joining` is a collector that concatenates the input elements into a String, in encounter order.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;
String s = Stream.of("a", "b", "c").collect(Collectors.joining(","));
System.out.println(s); // "a,b,c"

lessons.title: 85. LinkedHashMap Order
lessons.description: Preserve insertion order and print key:value pairs.
lessons.tutorial:
A HashMap stores key-value pairs. Use `put` to add items and `get` to retrieve them by key.

Example:

import java.util.HashMap;
HashMap capitals = new HashMap<>();
capitals.put("England", "London");
System.out.println(capitals.get("England")); // London

lessons.title: 86. LinkedHashSet Basics
lessons.description: Avoid duplicates and keep insertion order.
lessons.tutorial:
A `LinkedHashSet` is an ordered version of HashSet that maintains a doubly-linked List across all elements. The elements are ordered based on their insertion order.

Example:

import java.util.LinkedHashSet;
LinkedHashSet set = new LinkedHashSet<>();
set.add(3); set.add(1); set.add(3);
System.out.println(set); // [3, 1]

lessons.title: 87. TreeSet Sort
lessons.description: Store numbers in a sorted set and print ascending.
lessons.tutorial:
A `TreeSet` is a NavigableSet implementation based on a TreeMap. The elements are ordered using their natural ordering, or by a Comparator provided at set creation time.

Example:

import java.util.TreeSet;
TreeSet set = new TreeSet<>();
set.add(3); set.add(1);
System.out.println(set); // [1, 3]

lessons.title: 88. Comparable
lessons.description: Implement Comparable to sort custom objects.
lessons.tutorial:
The `Comparable` interface imposes a total ordering on the objects of each class that implements it. This ordering is referred to as the class's natural ordering.

Example:

class User implements Comparable {
    String name; User(String n){name=n;}
    public int compareTo(User o) { return name.compareTo(o.name); }
}
User u1=new User("Bob"), u2=new User("Alice");
System.out.println(u1.compareTo(u2) > 0); // true

lessons.title: 89. Default Methods
lessons.description: Use a default method in an interface.
lessons.tutorial:
Define reusable logic in methods. Static methods belong to the class and can be called without an instance.

Example:

static int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; }
System.out.println(add(3, 4)); // 7

lessons.title: 90. Abstract Class
lessons.description: Extend an abstract class and implement its method.
lessons.tutorial:
Abstract classes are similar to interfaces but can have fields that are not static and final, and they can contain non-abstract methods.

Example:

abstract class Shape { abstract double area(); }
class Circle extends Shape { double r=2; double area() {return 3.14*r*r;} }
System.out.println(new Circle().area()); // 12.56

lessons.title: 91. LocalDate
lessons.description: Parse a date and add one day.
lessons.tutorial:
`LocalDate` is an immutable date-time object that represents a date, often viewed as year-month-day.

Example:

import java.time.LocalDate;
LocalDate date = LocalDate.of(2023, 1, 31);
System.out.println(date.plusDays(1)); // 2023-02-01

lessons.title: 92. Regex Find
lessons.description: Use Pattern/Matcher to find digits in a string.
lessons.tutorial:
The `Matcher` class finds matches for a regular expression pattern in a string. The `find()` method scans the input sequence to find the next subsequence that matches the pattern.

Example:

import java.util.regex.*;
Matcher m = Pattern.compile("\\d+").matcher("a12b34c");
while (m.find()) { System.out.println(m.group()); } // 12, 34

lessons.title: 93. ArrayDeque
lessons.description: Use a deque to add/remove from both ends.
lessons.tutorial:
`ArrayDeque` is a resizable-array implementation of the `Deque` interface. It has no capacity restrictions and is faster than LinkedList for stack and queue operations.

Example:

import java.util.ArrayDeque;
ArrayDeque dq = new ArrayDeque<>();
dq.addFirst(1); dq.addLast(2);
System.out.println(dq.pollFirst()); // 1

lessons.title: 94. String.format
lessons.description: Format a string with placeholders.
lessons.tutorial:
`String.format()` returns a formatted string using the specified format string and arguments.

Example:

String s = String.format("Hello, %s! You have %d messages.", "Alice", 5);
System.out.println(s);

lessons.title: 95. Maven Coordinate Formatter
lessons.description: Format Maven coordinates as groupId:artifactId:version and print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
Maven artifacts are referenced by groupId:artifactId:version. Formatting these strings shows how dependencies are declared in pom.xml.

Example:

String coordinate = String.join(":", "org.projectlombok", "lombok", "1.18.30");
System.out.println(coordinate);

lessons.title: 96. Gradle Dependency Line
lessons.description: Print an implementation("group:artifact:version") line for Gradle build scripts.
lessons.tutorial:
Gradle's Kotlin/Groovy DSL wraps dependencies in method calls such as implementation("group:artifact:version"). Build scripts often use String.format or template literals to generate these entries.

Example:

String dep = String.format("testImplementation("%s:%s:%s")", "org.junit.jupiter", "junit-jupiter", "5.10.1");
System.out.println(dep);

lessons.title: 97. Git Branch Summary
lessons.description: Format a branch list so the current branch is marked with '*'.
lessons.tutorial:
Match Git's branch listing by marking the active branch with an asterisk.

Example:

for (String branch : branches) {
    String prefix = branch.equals(current) ? "* " : "  ";
    System.out.println(prefix + branch);
}

Formatting it like git branch keeps the practice output familiar.

lessons.title: 98. Git Merge Plan
lessons.description: Print the Git commands to merge a feature branch into main and show the commits that will be added.
lessons.expectedOutput:
git checkout main
git merge feature/login
Incoming commits: login-form, oauth
lessons.tutorial:
Summarize merge work by listing the commands you will run and the commits that will land. Tools like git log main..feature provide the same input.

Example:

System.out.println("git checkout " + target);
System.out.println("git merge " + source);
System.out.println("Incoming commits: " + String.join(", ", commits));

Spell out the post-merge history so reviewers can flag surprises before you run the command.

lessons.title: 99. Git Rebase Steps
lessons.description: Describe the commands to rebase a feature branch onto main and show the commits being replayed.
lessons.expectedOutput:
git checkout feature/search
git fetch origin main
git rebase origin/main
Replaying: index-view, search-ui
lessons.tutorial:
Rebasing keeps history linear. Listing the replayed commits double-checks what will be rewritten.

Example:

System.out.println("git checkout " + feature);
System.out.println("git fetch origin " + base);
System.out.println("git rebase origin/" + base);
System.out.println("Replaying: " + String.join(", ", commits));

Call out the origin branch explicitly so nobody rebases against stale local history.

lessons.title: 100. Git Conflict Resolution Practice
lessons.description: Walk through resolving merge conflicts by listing commands and the manual edit step.
lessons.expectedOutput:
git checkout main
git merge feature/landing
# resolve conflicts in templates/home.html
# resolve conflicts in static/site.css
git add templates/home.html static/site.css
git commit --no-edit
lessons.tutorial:
Conflict resolution is a routine workflow: merge, fix, stage, commit.

Example:

System.out.println("git checkout " + target);
System.out.println("git merge " + source);
for (String path : files) {
    System.out.println("# resolve conflicts in " + path);
}
System.out.println("git add " + String.join(" ", files));
System.out.println("git commit --no-edit");

Listing every conflicted file reassures reviewers you touched each one before committing.

lessons.title: 101. Git Cherry-pick Steps
lessons.description: Describe how to cherry-pick a set of commits onto a release branch and verify the history.
lessons.expectedOutput:
git checkout release/1.2
git cherry-pick feat-a1
git cherry-pick fix-a2
git log --oneline -5
lessons.tutorial:
Cherry-picking targeted fixes onto release branches is common during hotfix windows.

Example:

System.out.println("git checkout " + target);
for (String commit : commits) {
    System.out.println("git cherry-pick " + commit);
}
System.out.println("git log --oneline -5");

Close with a short log query so the team verifies the commits before tagging.

lessons.title: 102. Arrays.stream
lessons.description: Stream over a primitive array and sum it.
lessons.tutorial:
`Arrays.stream()` returns a sequential Stream with the specified array as its source.

Example:

import java.util.Arrays;
int[] arr = {1, 2, 3};
System.out.println(Arrays.stream(arr).sum()); // 6

lessons.title: 103. distinct()
lessons.description: Remove duplicates with distinct and print unique values.
lessons.tutorial:
The `distinct()` stream operation returns a stream consisting of the distinct elements (according to `Object.equals(Object)`) of this stream.

Example:

import java.util.stream.Stream;
Stream.of(1, 2, 1, 3).distinct().forEach(System.out::println); // 1, 2, 3

lessons.title: 104. groupingBy + TreeMap
lessons.description: Group words by length into a sorted map and print counts.
lessons.tutorial:
`Collectors.groupingBy` is used for grouping objects by some property and storing results in a Map instance.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;
import java.util.List;
System.out.println(Stream.of("a", "bb", "ccc", "dd").collect(Collectors.groupingBy(String::length))); // {1=[a], 2=[bb, dd], 3=[ccc]}

lessons.title: 105. flatMap
lessons.description: Flatten a list of lists and print each element.
lessons.tutorial:
`flatMap` transforms each element of a stream into another stream and then concatenates these streams into a single, "flattened" stream.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;
import java.util.List;
List> listOfLists = List.of(List.of(1), List.of(2, 3));
listOfLists.stream().flatMap(List::stream).forEach(System.out::println); // 1, 2, 3

lessons.title: 106. compute() Counts
lessons.description: Use Map.compute to count character frequency preserving first-seen order.
lessons.tutorial:
`Map.compute()` attempts to compute a mapping for the specified key and its current mapped value.

Example:

import java.util.HashMap;
HashMap map = new HashMap<>();
map.compute("key", (k, v) -> (v == null) ? 1 : v + 1);
System.out.println(map.get("key")); // 1

lessons.title: 107. partitioningBy
lessons.description: Partition numbers into even/odd and print counts.
lessons.tutorial:
`Collectors.partitioningBy` is a collector which partitions the input elements into a `Map>` according to a `Predicate`.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;
System.out.println(Stream.of(1,2,3,4).collect(Collectors.partitioningBy(n -> n%2==0))); // {false=[1, 3], true=[2, 4]}

lessons.title: 108. Thread vs Runnable
lessons.description: Create a Runnable that prints a message, start a Thread with it, then join the thread.
lessons.tutorial:
In Java, Runnable captures the work to do, while Thread controls execution. Wrap your runnable in a thread (or executor) and start it.

Example:

Runnable job = () -> System.out.println("Hi");
Thread t = new Thread(job);
t.start();
t.join();

lessons.title: 109. ExecutorService
lessons.description: Submit a Callable and print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
`ExecutorService` is a framework for asynchronous task execution. It manages a pool of threads and a task queue.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;
ExecutorService es = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
Future future = es.submit(() -> 1 + 1);
try { System.out.println(future.get()); } catch (Exception e) {}
es.shutdown();

lessons.title: 110. CompletableFuture
lessons.description: Compose async tasks and print the final result.
lessons.tutorial:
`CompletableFuture` is used for asynchronous programming. It represents a future result of an asynchronous computation.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture;
CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> "Result").thenAccept(System.out::println); // Result

lessons.title: 111. AtomicInteger
lessons.description: Safely increment a counter from two threads and print the total.
lessons.tutorial:
An `AtomicInteger` is an `int` value that may be updated atomically, making it useful in concurrent programming without locks.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;
AtomicInteger ai = new AtomicInteger(5);
System.out.println(ai.incrementAndGet()); // 6

lessons.title: 112. Optional.orElse
lessons.description: Provide a default value when Optional is empty.
lessons.tutorial:
`Optional.orElse()` returns the value if present, otherwise returns the other value.

Example:

import java.util.Optional;
String name = (String) Optional.ofNullable(null).orElse("default");
System.out.println(name); // default

lessons.title: 113. StringJoiner
lessons.description: Join strings with a custom delimiter.
lessons.tutorial:
String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

Example:

String s = "Java";
System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
System.out.println(s.length());

lessons.title: 114. BigDecimal
lessons.description: Add precise decimal numbers and print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
`BigDecimal` provides arbitrary-precision signed decimal numbers. Use it for financial calculations where precision is critical.

Example:

import java.math.BigDecimal;
BigDecimal a = new BigDecimal("0.1");
BigDecimal b = new BigDecimal("0.2");
System.out.println(a.add(b)); // 0.3

lessons.title: 115. replaceAll
lessons.description: Remove digits from a string using regex.
lessons.tutorial:
`String.replaceAll()` replaces each substring of this string that matches the given regular expression with the given replacement.

Example:

String s = "a1b2c3";
System.out.println(s.replaceAll("\\d", "#")); // a#b#c#

lessons.title: 116. Case-Insensitive Sort
lessons.description: Sort strings ignoring case and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
`String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER` is a `Comparator` that orders `String` objects as by `compareToIgnoreCase`.

Example:

import java.util.Arrays;
String[] arr = {"Bob", "alice"};
Arrays.sort(arr, String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER);
System.out.println(Arrays.toString(arr)); // [alice, Bob]

lessons.title: 117. String.repeat
lessons.description: Repeat a string and print it.
lessons.tutorial:
`String.repeat(n)` returns a string whose value is the concatenation of this string repeated `n` times.

Example:

System.out.println("-".repeat(5)); // -----

lessons.title: 118. Varargs
lessons.description: Implement a varargs sum method and print the sum.
lessons.tutorial:
Varargs allows a method to accept zero or more arguments. The varargs parameter is treated as an array of the specified type.

Example:

static int sum(int... nums) {
    return java.util.Arrays.stream(nums).sum();
}
System.out.println(sum(1, 2, 3)); // 6

lessons.title: 119. Interface Static Method
lessons.description: Call a static method defined on an interface.
lessons.tutorial:
Define reusable logic in methods. Static methods belong to the class and can be called without an instance.

Example:

static int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; }
System.out.println(add(3, 4)); // 7

lessons.title: 120. Try-with-Resources
lessons.description: Use try-with-resources to auto-close a reader.
lessons.tutorial:
The try-with-resources statement ensures that each resource is closed at the end of the statement. Any object that implements `AutoCloseable` can be used as a resource.

Example:

import java.io.*;
try (StringReader r = new StringReader("text")) {
    System.out.println((char)r.read()); // t
} catch (IOException e) {}

lessons.title: 121. PriorityQueue
lessons.description: Use a min-heap to get the smallest element.
lessons.tutorial:
A `PriorityQueue` is a heap-based queue where elements are ordered according to their natural ordering, or by a `Comparator`.

Example:

import java.util.PriorityQueue;
PriorityQueue pq = new PriorityQueue<>();
pq.add(3); pq.add(1);
System.out.println(pq.poll()); // 1

lessons.title: 122. LinkedList
lessons.description: Use LinkedList to add at the front and print first element.
lessons.tutorial:
ArrayList is a resizable list. Use add() to append and get() to access by index.

Example:

java.util.List list = new java.util.ArrayList<>();
list.add(1); list.add(2); list.add(3);
System.out.println(list);

lessons.title: 123. Deque push/pop
lessons.description: Use a Deque as a stack and print the popped value.
lessons.tutorial:
The `Deque` interface provides stack operations like `push` and `pop`. `ArrayDeque` is the recommended implementation.

Example:

import java.util.ArrayDeque;
ArrayDeque stack = new ArrayDeque<>();
stack.push(1); stack.push(2);
System.out.println(stack.pop()); // 2

lessons.title: 124. TreeMap
lessons.description: Insert keys into TreeMap and print the first key.
lessons.tutorial:
A `TreeMap` is a NavigableMap implementation that keeps its entries sorted according to the natural ordering of its keys, or by a `Comparator`.

Example:

import java.util.TreeMap;
TreeMap map = new TreeMap<>();
map.put(3, "c"); map.put(1, "a");
System.out.println(map.firstKey()); // 1

lessons.title: 125. StringBuilder.reverse
lessons.description: Reverse a string using StringBuilder and print it.
lessons.tutorial:
String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

Example:

String s = "Java";
System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
System.out.println(s.length());

lessons.title: 126. Regex Groups
lessons.description: Capture a group from a string and print it.
lessons.tutorial:
Parentheses `()` in a regex create capturing groups. You can access the captured text using `matcher.group(index)`.

Example:

import java.util.regex.*;
Matcher m = Pattern.compile("(\\d+)-(\w+)").matcher("123-xyz");
if (m.find()) { System.out.println(m.group(2)); } // xyz

lessons.title: 127. Arrays.binarySearch
lessons.description: Search a sorted array and print the index.
lessons.tutorial:
