`Arrays.binarySearch` searches the specified array for the specified value using the binary search algorithm. The array must be sorted.

Example:

import java.util.Arrays;
int[] arr = {10, 20, 30};
System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(arr, 20)); // 1

lessons.title: 128. Map.merge
lessons.description: Merge counts in a map and print the sum of counts for 'a' and 'b'.
lessons.tutorial:
`Map.merge` lets you update a map entry by applying a function to the old and new values.

Example:

import java.util.HashMap;
HashMap counts = new HashMap<>();
counts.merge("apple", 1, Integer::sum);
counts.merge("apple", 1, Integer::sum);
System.out.println(counts.get("apple")); // 2

lessons.title: 129. Capstone: Top Student
lessons.description: Use streams to find and print the highest-scoring student's name.
lessons.tutorial:
This capstone combines streams, comparators, and Optionals to find the object with the maximum value in a collection.

Example:

import java.util.*;
class S { String n; int s; S(String n, int s){this.n=n;this.s=s;} }
List list = List.of(new S("A",90), new S("B",100));
list.stream().max(Comparator.comparingInt(s -> s.s))
    .ifPresent(s -> System.out.println(s.n)); // B

lessons.title: 130. groupingBy counting
lessons.description: Count occurrences of letters using streams and print counts for 'a' then 'b'.
lessons.tutorial:
Use groupingBy with counting to aggregate items by key in one pass.

Example:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.function.Function;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;
List items = Arrays.asList("a", "b", "a");
Map m = items.stream()
  .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(Function.identity(), Collectors.counting()));
System.out.println(m.get("a")); // 2

lessons.title: 131. Optional.orElse
lessons.description: Find the first even number or return -1.
lessons.tutorial:
`Optional.orElse` provides a fallback when a value is absent.

Example:

import java.util.Optional;
System.out.println(Optional.<Integer>empty().orElse(42)); // 42

lessons.title: 132. Comparator.thenComparing
lessons.description: Sort by age then name and print the first person's name.
lessons.tutorial:
Chain comparators with thenComparing to apply tie-breakers for sorting.

Example:

list.sort(Comparator.comparingInt(Person::age)
    .thenComparing(Person::name));

lessons.title: 133. Concurrency Toolbox Overview
lessons.description: Implement pickTool(kind) to recommend a Java concurrency abstraction.
lessons.tutorial:
Threads, thread pools, and high-level futures each shine for different workloads. Pick executors for blocking I/O, CompletableFuture for pipelines of async tasks, and ForkJoinPool for CPU-heavy fork/join work.

Example:

switch (kind) {
    case "io-bound": return "ExecutorService";
    case "cpu-bound": return "ForkJoinPool";
    default: return "CompletableFuture";
}

lessons.title: 134. CompletableFuture.thenCombine
lessons.description: Combine two async computations and print their sum.
lessons.tutorial:
`CompletableFuture` supports composition. Use thenCombine to merge results of two futures.

Example:

CompletableFuture<Integer> a = CompletableFuture.completedFuture(1);
CompletableFuture<Integer> b = CompletableFuture.completedFuture(2);
System.out.println(a.thenCombine(b, Integer::sum).join());

lessons.title: 135. ExecutorService invokeAll
lessons.description: Run callables on a thread pool and sum their results.
lessons.tutorial:
`invokeAll` submits a batch of tasks and returns Futures you can collect results from.

Example:

ExecutorService es = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(4);
try { /* submit work */ } finally { es.shutdown(); }

lessons.title: 136. ArrayDeque as Stack
lessons.description: Push 1,2,3 then pop and print each on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
`ArrayDeque` implements the `Deque` interface and supports efficient stack operations.

Example:

ArrayDeque<String> s = new ArrayDeque<>();
s.push("x"); s.push("y");
System.out.println(s.pop()); // y

lessons.title: 137. TreeSet Comparator
lessons.description: Use a custom Comparator to sort by length then lexicographically and print the first element.
lessons.tutorial:
`TreeSet` orders its elements according to a Comparator you supply.

Example:

Comparator<String> byLen = Comparator.comparingInt(String::length);
TreeSet<String> set = new TreeSet<>(byLen.thenComparing(Comparator.naturalOrder()));

lessons.title: 138. LRU via LinkedHashMap
lessons.description: Limit size to 2 and print remaining keys after inserts.
lessons.tutorial:
Subclass `LinkedHashMap` and override `removeEldestEntry` to implement a simple LRU-style eviction by size.

Example:

LinkedHashMap<K,V> cache = new LinkedHashMap<>() {
  protected boolean removeEldestEntry(Map.Entry<K,V> e) { return size() > 100; }
};

lessons.title: 139. StringJoiner
lessons.description: Join strings with delimiter, prefix, and suffix.
lessons.tutorial:
`StringJoiner` helps build delimited strings with optional prefix/suffix.

Example:

StringJoiner sj = new StringJoiner(", ", "(", ")");
sj.add("x").add("y");
System.out.println(sj); // (x, y)

lessons.title: 140. BigDecimal Rounding
lessons.description: Round 2.456 to 2 decimal places using HALF_UP and print it.
lessons.tutorial:
Use `BigDecimal` for precise decimal arithmetic and control rounding.

Example:

new BigDecimal("1.005").setScale(2, RoundingMode.HALF_UP); // 1.01

lessons.title: 141. Capstone: Event Duration
lessons.description: Sum durations for CLICK events using streams and print the total.
lessons.tutorial:
Combine filtering and aggregation in a stream pipeline to compute metrics from domain objects.

Example:

int sum = list.stream().filter(x -> x > 0).mapToInt(Integer::intValue).sum();

lessons.title: 142. Map.merge (counting)
lessons.description: Use Map.merge to count occurrences and print the count for 'a'.
lessons.tutorial:
Map.merge simplifies counters: initialize when absent, otherwise combine with a function (e.g., Integer::sum).

Example:

java.util.Map m = new java.util.HashMap<>();
m.merge("k", 1, Integer::sum);

lessons.title: 143. LinkedHashSet (dedupe, preserve order)
lessons.description: Remove duplicates while preserving insertion order and print the size.
lessons.tutorial:
LinkedHashSet preserves insertion order while removing duplicates.

Example:

import java.util.*;

lessons.title: 144. groupingBy + summingInt

lessons.title: 154. Capstone: Word Count Top2
lessons.description: Count words and print the top 2 by frequency (key:count).
lessons.tutorial:
Combine groupingBy+counting with a custom sort to get top-k frequencies.

Example:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String s = "a b a c b b";
        Map<String, Long> m = Arrays.stream(s.split(" ")).collect(Collectors.groupingBy(x -> x, Collectors.counting()));
        m.entrySet().stream()
            .sorted((e1,e2) -> Long.compare(e2.getValue(), e1.getValue()))
            .limit(2)
            .forEach(e -> System.out.println(e.getKey()+":"+e.getValue()));
    }

lessons.title: 155. Capstone: CompletableFuture Timeout
lessons.description: Use completeOnTimeout to return 'fast' if slow task exceeds 100ms.
lessons.tutorial:
Bound latency by completing a future with a fallback if it exceeds a deadline.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        CompletableFuture<String> slow = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> {
            try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); }
            return "slow";
        });
        System.out.println(slow.completeOnTimeout("fast", 100, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS).join());
    }
}

Parallel streams can speed up CPU-bound aggregations on large ranges.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {

lessons.title: 158. Capstone: CountDownLatch
lessons.description: Coordinate two threads and print 'done' after both complete.
lessons.tutorial:
Use CountDownLatch to wait for a set of operations to complete.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        CountDownLatch latch = new CountDownLatch(2);
        Runnable r = () -> { try { Thread.sleep(50); } catch (InterruptedException e) {} finally { latch.countDown(); } };
        new Thread(r).start();
        new Thread(r).start();
        latch.await();
        System.out.println("done");
    }
}

rw.readLock().lock(); try { /* read */ } finally { rw.readLock().unlock(); }

lessons.title: 178. ReentrantLock
lessons.description: Protect a shared counter with ReentrantLock across two threads and print 2000.
lessons.tutorial:
ReentrantLock offers explicit locking with try/finally for predictable release; it supports advanced features beyond synchronized.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.locks.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Lock lock = new ReentrantLock();
        final int[] counter = {0};
        Runnable inc = () -> {
            for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
                lock.lock();
                try { counter[0]++; } finally { lock.unlock(); }
            }
        };

public class Main {

    static final class Rect implements Shape { int w,h; Rect(int w,int h){ this.w=w; this.h=h; } }
    static final class Circle implements Shape { int r; Circle(int r){ this.r=r; } }
    public static void main(String[] args) {

            System.out.println(r.w * r.h);
        }
    }
}

allOf waits for multiple futures; use a continuation to compose their results.

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {

lessons.title: 185. AutoCloseable (custom resource)

lessons.title: 192. ExecutorService invokeAll (sum squares)

lessons.tutorial:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        ExecutorService es = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(3);
        try {
            List<Callable<Integer>> tasks = Arrays.asList(
                () -> 1*1, () -> 2*2, () -> 3*3
            );
            int sum = 0;
            for (Future<Integer> f : es.invokeAll(tasks)) { sum += f.get(); }

import java.util.*;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {

lessons.title: 198. Regex: extract digits
lessons.description: Remove non-digits from 'a1b22c' and print '122'.
lessons.tutorial:
\D matches non-digits; replacing them with empty string keeps only digits.

Example:

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    String s = "a1b22c";
    System.out.println(s.replaceAll("\\D", ""));
  }
}

lessons.title: 199. LocalDate: days between
lessons.description: Compute days between 2024-01-10 and 2024-01-15 (5).
lessons.tutorial:
Use ChronoUnit.DAYS.between to compute date differences.

Example:

import java.time.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    LocalDate a = LocalDate.parse("2024-01-10");
    LocalDate b = LocalDate.parse("2024-01-15");
    System.out.println(java.time.temporal.ChronoUnit.DAYS.between(a, b));
  }
}

lessons.title: 200. Optional.ifPresentOrElse
lessons.description: Use ifPresentOrElse to print 'EMPTY' for an empty Optional.
lessons.tutorial:
ifPresentOrElse eliminates branching boilerplate for presence/absence.

Example:

import java.util.*;

public class Main {

    Optional<String> s = Optional.empty();

}

lessons.title: 201. record basics
lessons.description: Define a record Point(x,y), create (3,4), and print x+y (7).
lessons.tutorial:
A record declares an immutable data carrier with generated accessors.

}

lessons.title: 202. Collectors.joining
lessons.description: Join [a,b,c] with commas and print 'a,b,c'.
lessons.tutorial:
Collectors.joining concatenates strings with a delimiter.

Example:

import java.util.*;

public class Main {

lessons.title: 203. Map.computeIfPresent (remove when zero)
lessons.description: Decrement a counter to zero and remove it; print map size (0).
lessons.tutorial:
Use computeIfPresent for atomic updates; remove entries when counters hit zero.

Example:

import java.util.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Map<String,Integer> m = new HashMap<>();
    m.put("a", 2);
    m.computeIfPresent("a", (k,v) -> v - 2);
    m.remove("a", 0);
    System.out.println(m.size());
  }
}

lessons.title: 204. Case-insensitive reverse sort
lessons.description: Sort [b,A,c] case-insensitively in descending order and print each on its own line.
lessons.tutorial:
Use String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER.reversed() for case-insensitive descending order.

import java.util.*;

public class Main {

    List<String> xs = Arrays.asList("b","A","c");
    xs.sort(String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER.reversed());
    for (String s : xs) System.out.println(s);
  }
}

lessons.title: 205. ArrayDeque as stack

ArrayDeque efficiently implements a stack with push/pop.

import java.util.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Deque<Integer> dq = new ArrayDeque<>();
    dq.push(1); dq.push(2); dq.push(3);
    while (!dq.isEmpty()) System.out.println(dq.pop());
  }
}

lessons.title: 206. BigDecimal rounding

lessons.title: 207. Files.list (count directories)
lessons.description: Create d/a and d/b directories (and a file), then print directory count (2).
lessons.tutorial:
Use Files.list with Files::isDirectory to count subdirectories.

Example:

import java.nio.file.*;
import java.io.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    Path d = Paths.get("d");
    Files.createDirectories(d.resolve("a"));
    Files.createDirectories(d.resolve("b"));

lessons.title: 208. groupingBy counting
lessons.description: Count by first character and print count for key 'a' (2).
lessons.tutorial:
Combine groupingBy with counting to build frequency maps.

Example:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    List<String> xs = Arrays.asList("ax","ay","bz");
    Map<Character,Long> m = xs.stream().collect(Collectors.groupingBy(s -> s.charAt(0), Collectors.counting()));
    System.out.println(m.get('a'));
  }
}

lessons.title: 209. CompletableFuture.thenCombine
lessons.description: Combine two async computations (2 and 3) and print their sum (5).
lessons.tutorial:
thenCombine merges results from two independent futures.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    CompletableFuture<Integer> a = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 2);
    CompletableFuture<Integer> b = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 3);
    System.out.println(a.thenCombine(b, Integer::sum).join());
  }
}

lessons.title: 210. CompletableFuture.anyOf
lessons.description: Return the first of two futures (fast vs slow) and print 'fast'.
lessons.tutorial:
anyOf completes with the first finished future; use join() to get the result.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
  static void sleep(long ms) { try { Thread.sleep(ms); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } }
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    CompletableFuture<String> fast = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> { sleep(50); return "fast"; });
    CompletableFuture<String> slow = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> { sleep(200); return "slow"; });
    System.out.println((String) CompletableFuture.anyOf(fast, slow).join());
  }
}

lessons.title: 211. Files.lines + filter + sum
lessons.description: Write 1,3,5 to a file, filter >2, sum and print 8.
lessons.tutorial:
Combine Files.lines with stream filters and reductions for file processing.

Example:

import java.nio.file.*;
import java.io.*;
import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    Path d = Paths.get("d");
    Files.createDirectories(d);
    Path p = d.resolve("n.txt");
    Files.writeString(p, "1\n3\n5\n");
    long s = Files.lines(p).map(String::trim).filter(x -> !x.isEmpty()).mapToLong(Long::parseLong).filter(v -> v > 2).sum();
    System.out.println(s);

lessons.title: 212. StringBuilder.reverse

lessons.title: 213. TreeMap floor/ceiling

lessons.title: 214. EnumSet basics

lessons.title: 224. groupingBy first letter (counts)

lessons.title: 229. JUnit-Style Smoke Test

JUnit finds methods marked with @Test and reports pass/fail counts. You can mimic that feedback loop with a lightweight reflection runner.

while (i <= mid && j <= right) { ... }

dp[value] = Math.min(dp[value], dp[value - coin] + 1);

int idx = Collections.binarySearch(tails, num);

lessons.description: Print the network investigation commands in order.
