Network Diagnostics Checklist
Latency: mtr --report 10 api.prod
Packet capture: sudo tcpdump -ni eth0 host 203.0.113.8
DNS: dig +trace api.prod
HTTP timing: curl -w '
connect: %{time_connect}s total: %{time_total}s
' https://api.prod/health
lessons.tutorial:
A predictable checklist keeps network triage focused-latency, captures, DNS, and HTTP timing cover the common failure angles.

Pattern:

for (Map.Entry entry : checks.entrySet()) {
  System.out.println(entry.getKey() + ": " + entry.getValue());
}

lessons.title: 254. Behavioral Story Outline: Incident Leadership
lessons.description: Turn the STAR components into a structured incident leadership story.
lessons.expectedOutput:
STAR Incident Leadership Story
Situation: Peak sale traffic saturated checkout service
Task: Restore cart checkout under 10 minutes
Actions:
- Declared incident and spun up war room
- Throttled recommendation calls at ingress
- Coordinated rollback of faulty feature flag
Result: Checkout error rate dropped from 35% to 1.2% in 7 minutes
lessons.tutorial:
Executives listen for situational awareness, decisive action, and measurable impact-STAR keeps the story sharp.

Template:

System.out.println("Actions:");

lessons.title: 255. SQL SELECT Builder: Active Customers
lessons.description: Build a SELECT statement string using the provided columns, table, predicate, and order clause.
lessons.expectedOutput: SELECT id, email, tier FROM customers WHERE status = 'ACTIVE' ORDER BY last_login DESC;
lessons.tutorial:
A SELECT statement needs to spell out columns, the table, filters, and sort order. Commas separate selected columns, while clauses like WHERE and ORDER BY fine-tune results.

Example:

SELECT id, email FROM customers WHERE status = 'ACTIVE' ORDER BY last_login DESC;

Combine the provided values into one SQL statement and end it with a semicolon.

lessons.title: 256. SQL JOIN Builder: Orders + Payments
lessons.description: Format a multi-line SQL query that joins orders to customers and payments with the supplied segments.
lessons.expectedOutput:
SELECT o.id, o.total, c.email, p.status
FROM orders o
JOIN customers c ON c.id = o.customer_id
LEFT JOIN payments p ON p.order_id = o.id
WHERE o.state = 'PAID' AND o.region = 'NA';
lessons.tutorial:
Line breaks keep complex joins readable: list the SELECT columns, show the base table, then stack each JOIN and the final WHERE clause.

Example:

SELECT o.id, o.total
FROM orders o
JOIN customers c ON c.id = o.customer_id;

Print each segment on its own line and combine the filters with AND.

lessons.title: 257. Index Strategy Summary
lessons.description: Summarize the primary, covering, and partial indexes defined for the orders table.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Index Strategy: orders
Primary key: orders_pkey (id)
Covering indexes:
- idx_orders_state_status on (state, status)
- idx_orders_customer_created on (customer_id, created_at DESC)
Partial index:
- idx_orders_ready WHERE status = 'READY_TO_SHIP'
lessons.tutorial:
Senior engineers need to reason about which queries each index accelerates. Call out the primary key, covering indexes for critical filters, and any partial indexes that trim dead rows.

Example:

Primary key: orders_pkey (id)
- idx_orders_state_status on (state, status)

Format the summary with headings and bullet points so the intent of each index is obvious.

lessons.title: 258. JPA Entity Outline: Order
lessons.description: Use the provided field definitions to print a minimal JPA entity annotated for the orders table.
lessons.tutorial:
Annotating entities with @Entity and @Table makes the mapping explicit for ORMs. Keep each field's annotations aligned so constraints jump out during code review.

Example:

@Entity
@Table(name = "orders")
public class Order { ... }

Use the supplied metadata to print the full snippet with proper indentation.

lessons.title: 259. Spring Data Repository Sketch
lessons.description: Print a repository interface with imports and query methods for the Order aggregate.
lessons.tutorial:
Repository interfaces pull persistence operations into one place. List your imports first, then declare finder methods that match how the service layer reads data.

Example:

public interface OrderRepository extends JpaRepository<Order, Long> { ... }

Output the full interface including imports so the snippet is copy-paste ready.

lessons.title: 260. Transactional Service Flow
lessons.description: Lay out the ordered steps for a transactional order reservation use case.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Transactional Order Flow
1. load order with FOR UPDATE
2. check inventory via InventoryGateway
3. reserve stock and update order status
4. publish OrderReserved event
lessons.tutorial:
Mission-critical flows should spell out each transactional hop so you can reason about locking and side effects.

Example:

1. load order with FOR UPDATE
2. adjust state

Print the numbered sequence to highlight the order of operations inside the transaction boundary.

lessons.title: 261. Spring Security Filter Chain Plan
lessons.description: Summarize the key rules required to secure the order API.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Security Filter Chain
- disable CSRF for token API
- add JWTAuthenticationFilter before UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter
- require ROLE_ADMIN for POST /admin/**
- permitAll for GET /status
lessons.tutorial:
Documenting the filter chain clarifies which requests are locked down versus publicly accessible.

Example:

- require ROLE_ADMIN for POST /admin/**

Keep the bullets terse so each rule is easy to scan.

lessons.title: 262. Integration Test Checklist: Order API
lessons.description: List the container, migration, seeding, and verification steps for a full-stack test.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Integration Test Checklist
- start PostgreSQL Testcontainer
- apply schema migrations
- seed reference products
- call POST /orders
- assert 201 status and location header
- query database for saved order
lessons.tutorial:
Repeatable integration tests stand up real infrastructure, exercise the API, and verify persistence side effects.

Example:

- start PostgreSQL Testcontainer
- run migrations

List each step so failures are easy to localize when tests go red.

lessons.title: 263. Docker Compose Outline: Order Service
lessons.description: Summarize the docker-compose services, including builds, environment variables, and dependencies.
lessons.expectedOutput:
docker-compose.yml
services:
- app -> build ./, env SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod, depends_on db
- db -> image postgres:16, env POSTGRES_DB=orders, volumes ./data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
lessons.tutorial:
Container orchestration plans should capture how services start, which images they use, and the configuration they need.

Example:

- app -> build ./, env SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE=prod

Iterate in insertion order so the summary mirrors a docker-compose file.

lessons.title: 264. CI Pipeline Stages: Order Service
lessons.description: List the continuous integration stages needed before shipping the service.
lessons.expectedOutput:
CI Pipeline
1. checkout
2. setup JDK 21
3. cache ~/.m2
4. run ./mvnw verify
5. build docker image
6. push artifact to registry
lessons.tutorial:
High-signal pipelines make build, test, and packaging stages explicit so failures point to the right fix.

Example:

1. checkout
2. run tests

Print each stage with its sequence number to show the promotion path toward production.

lessons.title: 265. Kubernetes Deployment Snippet
lessons.description: Output the key manifest lines for running the service on Kubernetes.
lessons.expectedOutput:
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: orders-api
spec:
  replicas: 3
  template:
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: app
        image: ghcr.io/acme/orders:latest
        env:
        - name: SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE
          value: prod
lessons.tutorial:
Kubernetes manifests depend on precise indentation. Capture the apiVersion, resource kind, metadata, and container spec.

Example:

kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: orders-api

Print the manifest lines exactly so they can be dropped into a deployment file.

lessons.title: 266. AWS Reference Stack: Orders
lessons.description: Summarize the core AWS services powering the production deployment.
lessons.expectedOutput:
AWS Reference Stack
- API Gateway -> Lambda webhook fanout
- ECS service -> orders-api (Fargate, 3 tasks)
- RDS cluster -> aurora-postgresql
- SQS queue -> orders-events
- CloudWatch alarms -> p95 latency > 500ms
lessons.tutorial:
Tie each AWS service to the responsibility it owns so stakeholders understand the deployment topology.

Example:

- RDS cluster -> aurora-postgresql

Keep the bullet list concise but descriptive enough to guide on-call responders.

lessons.title: 267. Observability Instrumentation Map
lessons.description: Describe the metrics, logs, and traces that give production insight into orders.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Observability Plan
Metrics:
- order_submitted_total (counter)
- payment_latency_seconds (histogram)
Logs:
- structured JSON with orderId, traceId, status
Traces:
- name HTTP POST /orders
- inject traceparent header to downstream
lessons.tutorial:
Great observability stories connect metrics, logs, and traces so incidents can be triaged quickly.

Example:

Metrics:
- order_submitted_total (counter)

Group instrumentation by signal type to highlight coverage gaps.

lessons.title: 268. Resume Bullet Transformer
lessons.description: Convert accomplishment data into a compelling resume bullet.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Resume Bullet
Scaled Spring Boot order service to 120k req/min by introducing Redis caching and async fulfillment; cut p95 from 940ms to 210ms.
lessons.tutorial:
Elite resumes lead with scope, highlight the leverage you applied, and quantify the outcome.

Example:

Scaled platform X by doing Y; improved metric Z.

Weave the provided fragments into one strong sentence.

lessons.title: 269. Senior Interview Prep Sprint
lessons.description: Draft a five-day prep plan covering system design, coding, behavioral, architecture, and negotiation drills.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Interview Prep Sprint
Day 1: system design -> design global rate limiter
Day 2: coding -> implement LRU cache in 30 min
Day 3: behavioral -> lead incident retrospective story
Day 4: architecture -> review microservice observability
Day 5: negotiation -> target base + equity bands
lessons.tutorial:
A deliberate prep sprint keeps you sharp across all interview formats while preventing last-minute panic.

Example:

Day 1: system design -> practice high-scale feeds

Print the plan in order so it doubles as a checklist during your prep week.

lessons.title: 270. Error Budget Dashboard Row
lessons.description: Given counts and budget limits, calculate the current error rate and remaining budget, then print the production status lines.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Service: auth-api
Requests: 100000
Errors: 420
Error Rate: 0.42%
Budget Remaining: 1.58%
lessons.tutorial:
Site reliability dashboards need a quick readout of burn rate. Divide errors by total requests to get the percent burn, then subtract from your budget.

Example:

double errorRate = (failures / (double) requests) * 100;
System.out.printf("Error Rate: %.2f%%%n", errorRate);

Use %.2f to lock to two decimals so the report looks consistent across teams.

lessons.title: 271. Incident Timeline Reporter
lessons.description: Loop through the incident events and print a well-formatted timeline for the postmortem.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Incident Timeline
07:05 - PagerDuty triggered for elevated 5xx
07:09 - Incident commander assigned
07:14 - Rolled back payment service
07:21 - Error rates normalized
lessons.tutorial:
After every outage you publish a crisp minute-by-minute log. Store each entry as a two-item array so you can unpack it in a for-each loop.

Example:

for (String[] event : events) {
    System.out.printf("%s - %s%n", event[0], event[1]);
}

The heading makes the block paste-ready for your incident doc.

lessons.title: 272. Canary Analysis Summary
lessons.description: Compare baseline and canary signals and print the difference so release managers can decide to promote.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Canary Analysis
latency_p95_ms: baseline=340, canary=360, delta=+20.00
error_rate_pct: baseline=0.70, canary=0.90, delta=+0.20
cpu_pct: baseline=52, canary=49, delta=-3.00
lessons.tutorial:
Canary comparisons reveal regressions before a full rollout. Keep the output structured so the release manager can skim each signal.

Example:

double delta = values[1] - values[0];
System.out.printf("delta=%+.2f%n", delta);

Formatting whole numbers without decimals keeps the table tidy, while the %+ flag shows direction.

lessons.title: 273. Feature Flag Rollout Planner
lessons.description: Turn the staged rollout data into a checklist operations can follow without ambiguity.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Feature Flag Plan
Flag: checkout_redesign
Stage 1: 5% - internal users only
Stage 2: 25% - beta cohort rollout
Stage 3: 50% - enable for all EU traffic
Stage 4: 100% - global enablement
lessons.tutorial:
Successful launches follow a staged plan. Loop by index so you can pull the matching percentage and note for each milestone.

Example:

for (int i = 0; i < notes.length; i++) {
    System.out.printf("Stage %d: %d%%%n", i + 1, percentages[i]);
}

Printing the flag name up front makes the output self-contained in chat threads.

lessons.title: 274. Capacity Forecast Table
lessons.description: Project the expected requests per second for the next three quarters by compounding growth.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Capacity Forecast
Q1: 2070 rps
Q2: 2525 rps
Q3: 2980 rps
lessons.tutorial:
Capacity reviews rely on compounding growth so finance can model hardware spend. Multiply the running total by each rate in turn.

Example:

projected *= 1 + growthRates[i];
System.out.printf("%d rps%n", Math.round(projected));

Pair each percentage with its quarter label to keep the forecast legible.

lessons.title: 275. Service Dependency Matrix
lessons.description: Summarize each platform service with its owning team and downstream dependencies.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Service Dependencies
checkout (team: Growth) -> payments, inventory, notifications
payments (team: Core Banking) -> risk, ledger
search (team: Discovery) -> none
lessons.tutorial:
Platform diagrams pair each service with its owning team and the downstream systems it calls. A LinkedHashMap keeps the ordering stable so you can print the analysis exactly as documented.

Example:

for (Map.Entry> entry : services.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println(entry.getKey());
}

Use String.join(...) to flatten the dependency list, and fall back to "none" when a service has no downstream calls.

lessons.title: 276. Incident Action Agenda
lessons.description: Turn the post-incident actions into a one-glance checklist with owners and due dates.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Incident Action Items
- SRE to Add circuit breaker to retries (due 2024-08-01)
- Platform to Publish synthetic monitor runbook (due 2024-08-05)
- Incident Lead to Schedule chaos drill follow up (due 2024-08-12)
lessons.tutorial:
Incident follow-ups stick when every task has an owner and a date. Loop through the 2D array and unpack each slot so the printout reads like a runbook checklist.

Example:

for (String[] action : actions) {
    System.out.println(action[1] + " -> " + action[0]);
}

Formatting with System.out.printf keeps the bullets consistent when you paste them into the team's tracker.

lessons.title: 277. Architecture Trade-off Matrix
lessons.description: Compare architecture options on speed, delivery effort, and operational load for review with staff engineers.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Architecture Trade-offs
Monolith - latency: 140ms, build: 4 weeks, ops: low
Services - latency: 95ms, build: 10 weeks, ops: high
Event Hub - latency: 120ms, build: 7 weeks, ops: medium
lessons.tutorial:
Staff-level discussions start with data. Loop through the matrix and print each row with printf so the comparison reads naturally.

Example:

for (String[] option : options) {
    System.out.println(option[0]);
}

Consistent formatting helps the team reason about which design wins.

lessons.title: 278. Reliability Risk Register
lessons.description: Score platform risks by multiplying impact and likelihood before presenting to incident commanders.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Reliability Risk Register
Checkout API - impact: 5, likelihood: 3, severity: 15
Worker Queue - impact: 4, likelihood: 2, severity: 8
Search Index - impact: 3, likelihood: 4, severity: 12
lessons.tutorial:
Translate qualitative risk talk into numbers leaders can act on. Multiply matching indices to compute severity.

Example:

int severity = impact * likelihood;
System.out.println(severity);

This table lets you argue for the mitigations that matter.

lessons.title: 279. Migration Cutover Timeline
lessons.description: Sequence migration activities with owners so the war room has a single source of truth.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Migration Cutover Timeline
T-24h: Platform -> freeze writes
T-6h: DBA -> back up primary database
T-0: SRE -> switch traffic to new cluster
T+1h: QA -> run smoke tests
lessons.tutorial:
Cutover calls move fast. Loop through the table so everyone sees time, owner, and action in one line.

Example:

for (String[] step : steps) {
    System.out.println(step[0]);
}

Clear sequencing avoids duplicated work and missed checkpoints.

lessons.title: 280. Security Control Coverage
lessons.description: Group controls by security domain before meeting with compliance and risk teams.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Security Control Coverage
Authentication:
- MFA enforcement
- Session timeout review
Data Protection:
- Rotate KMS keys
- Encrypt S3 buckets
Observability:
- Audit log retention
- Alert on IAM anomalies
lessons.tutorial:
Organize controls by domain so audits run smoothly. A nested loop keeps each heading grouped with its actions.

Example:

for (String control : domains.get("Authentication")) {
    System.out.println(control);
}

Readable summaries help security and engineering stay aligned.

lessons.title: 281. Cost Efficiency Report
lessons.description: Show spend deltas and percentage change so finance trusts the engineering savings narrative.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Cost Efficiency Report
api-gateway: baseline=$3200, current=$2800, delta=$-400, change=-12.5%
batch-jobs: baseline=$4100, current=$4800, delta=$+700, change=+17.1%
stream-processor: baseline=$2900, current=$2550, delta=$-350, change=-12.1%
lessons.tutorial:
Partner teams want signed numbers. Use %+d and %+.1f so the reader sees direction immediately.

Example:

System.out.printf("delta=%+d", delta);
System.out.printf("change=%+.1f%%", change);

That visibility makes budget reviews smoother.

lessons.title: 282. Mentorship Pairing Planner
lessons.description: List mentor pairings and focus areas to reinforce talent development across squads.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Mentorship Pairings
Alice -> Ravi: modernize reporting ETL
Morgan -> Chen: k8s deployment playbook
Jamie -> Inez: observability dashboards
lessons.tutorial:
Mentorship plans show leadership maturity. Print each tuple in a single line so managers can copy the plan straight into trackers.

Example:

for (String[] pairing : pairings) {
    System.out.println(pairing[0]);
}

Concise formatting keeps the focus on the growth goals.

lessons.title: 283. Roadmap Pillar Summary
lessons.description: Group initiatives by pillar so cross-functional leaders can review strategy quickly.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Roadmap Pillars
Reliability:
- Implement region failover
- Drop MTTR below 20m
Product:
- Adaptive pricing
- Cross-store search
Platform:
- Unified CI/CD pipeline
lessons.tutorial:
Strategic storytelling is a senior skill. Use a nested loop to keep initiatives grouped with their pillar.

Example:

System.out.println("Platform:");
System.out.println("- Unified CI/CD pipeline");

Readable summaries help execs process the plan quickly.

lessons.title: 284. Experiment Result Synthesizer
lessons.description: Report experiment deltas and percentage lift so launch decisions stay data-driven.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Experiment Results
Checkout copy (conversion): delta=+0.019, lift=+5.56%
Recommendation ranking (session revenue): delta=+0.250, lift=+3.21%
lessons.tutorial:
Launch reviews need both absolute and relative movement. Use %+.3f for signed deltas and %+.2f for lift so decisions stay grounded.

Example:

double delta = treatment - control;
System.out.printf("%+.3f", delta);

Consistent formatting means no one has to recompute the numbers mid-meeting.

lessons.title: 285. StampedLock optimistic read
lessons.description: Write 42 under a StampedLock and read it back with an optimistic read fallback.
lessons.tutorial:
StampedLock supports optimistic reads: grab a stamp with tryOptimisticRead() and fall back to a read lock if another writer intervened.

Example:

StampedLock lock = new StampedLock();
long stamp = lock.tryOptimisticRead();
if (!lock.validate(stamp)) {
    stamp = lock.readLock();
    lock.unlockRead(stamp);
}

lessons.title: 286. Phaser phase coordination
lessons.description: Coordinate two workers through a two-phase barrier and print progress from the main thread.
lessons.tutorial:
Phaser lets you synchronize dynamic parties over multiple phases. Each arriveAndAwaitAdvance() blocks until all registered parties reach the same phase.

Example:

Phaser ph = new Phaser(3);
ph.arriveAndAwaitAdvance(); // release workers
ph.arriveAndAwaitAdvance(); // wait for completion

lessons.title: 287. LinkedBlockingQueue producer/consumer
lessons.description: Use a LinkedBlockingQueue to sum produced values and print the total once both threads finish.
lessons.tutorial:
A BlockingQueue coordinates producer and consumer threads without busy waiting. Use a sentinel to signal completion.

Example:

BlockingQueue q = new LinkedBlockingQueue<>();
q.put(1);
int v = q.take();

lessons.title: 288. CompletableFuture.handle
lessons.description: Recover from a failed async computation with handle and print a fallback value.
lessons.tutorial:
handle sees both the value and the exception. Combine it with failedFuture to model failure and supply a fallback without branching helpers.

Example:

CompletableFuture.failedFuture(new RuntimeException())
    .handle((v, ex) -> ex == null ? v : "fallback");

lessons.title: 289. CyclicBarrier rendezvous
lessons.description: Use a CyclicBarrier to pause two worker threads until the main thread reaches the barrier, then print release and done.
lessons.tutorial:
A CyclicBarrier lets multiple threads rendezvous at the same point before proceeding. The optional barrier action runs once when the last party arrives.

Example:

CyclicBarrier barrier = new CyclicBarrier(3, () -> System.out.println("trip"));
barrier.await();

lessons.title: 290. ExecutorCompletionService gather
lessons.description: Collect tasks as they finish using ExecutorCompletionService and print results in completion order.
lessons.tutorial:
ExecutorCompletionService wraps a pool and yields completed tasks as they finish, so you can react in completion order without polling.

Example:

CompletionService cs = new ExecutorCompletionService<>(pool);
cs.submit(callable);
Future done = cs.take();

lessons.title: 291. ConcurrentLinkedQueue audit
lessons.description: Add and remove items from a ConcurrentLinkedQueue and print the values observed.
lessons.tutorial:
Use ConcurrentLinkedQueue for lock-free, thread-safe queues suited to producer/consumer patterns.

Example:

ConcurrentLinkedQueue q = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<>();
q.offer("event");
String item = q.poll();

lessons.title: 292. DelayQueue ordering
lessons.description: Use a DelayQueue to delay two tasks and show that take() returns them in readiness order.
lessons.tutorial:
A DelayQueue releases elements only after their delay expires. Implement Delayed and use take() to block until the head is ready.

Example:

DelayQueue q = new DelayQueue<>();
q.put(new MyTask(100));
System.out.println(q.take());

Even if you enqueue slower tasks first, the queue orders by remaining delay.

lessons.title: 293. CompletableFuture applyToEither
lessons.description: Race two futures with applyToEither and print the winning result with a suffix.
lessons.tutorial:
Use applyToEither to react to whichever future completes first. The slower branch is still allowed to finish, but you can ignore or cancel it if desired.

Example:

primary.applyToEither(backup, x -> x + " ok")
       .thenAccept(System.out::println);

This is perfect for primary/backup calls where you just need the fastest healthy response.

lessons.title: 294. Exchanger handoff
lessons.description: Swap messages between two threads with Exchanger and print the one received by main.
lessons.tutorial:
An Exchanger is a rendezvous point where two threads swap objects. Each exchange call blocks until a partner arrives.

Example:

String fromPeer = exchanger.exchange("data");

Use it to hand buffers back and forth between producer and consumer phases without extra queues.

lessons.title: 295. SynchronousQueue rendezvous
lessons.description: Coordinate a handoff with SynchronousQueue so the consumer prints the produced value.
lessons.tutorial:
A SynchronousQueue has no capacity: producers block until a consumer takes, and vice versa. It's ideal for direct handoffs.

Example:

SynchronousQueue q = new SynchronousQueue<>();
new Thread(() -> q.put("ready")).start();
System.out.println(q.take());

This pattern keeps pressure low when you only need to transfer ownership of a single item at a time.

lessons.title: 296. LongAccumulator max
lessons.description: Use a LongAccumulator with a max function to track the highest value submitted from multiple tasks and print 42.
lessons.tutorial:
Use LongAccumulator to combine values across threads without explicit locking. Supply a function (max, sum, etc.) and an identity seed.

Example:

LongAccumulator max = new LongAccumulator(Long::max, Long.MIN_VALUE);
max.accumulate(10);
max.accumulate(42);
System.out.println(max.get()); // 42

Accumulators scale under contention better than synchronized counters.

lessons.title: 297. CompletableFuture.orTimeout fail fast
lessons.description: Trigger a timeout on a slow CompletableFuture using orTimeout and recover to print "timeout".
lessons.tutorial:
Use orTimeout to automatically fail a slow stage instead of waiting indefinitely.

Example:

CompletableFuture slow = ...;
slow.orTimeout(100, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
    .exceptionally(ex -> "fallback")
    .join();

Timeouts keep latency budgets enforced without custom scheduling code.

lessons.title: 298. Stream.mapMulti flatten groups
lessons.description: Flatten nested lists with mapMulti and print "1 2 3 4".
lessons.tutorial:
mapMulti lets you push zero, one, or many elements downstream without creating intermediate streams.

Example:

stream.mapMulti((list, downstream) -> {
    for (var item : list) {
        downstream.accept(item);
    }
});

It avoids allocation compared to flatMap when you already have iterable data.

lessons.title: 299. Collectors.teeing min/max summary
lessons.description: Use Collectors.teeing to compute min and max from numbers and print "min=2 max=11".
lessons.tutorial:
Combine two collectors in one pass with Collectors.teeing for efficient summaries.

Example:

var summary = numbers.stream()
    .collect(Collectors.teeing(
        Collectors.counting(),
        Collectors.averagingDouble(x -> x),
        (count, avg) -> count + "/" + avg
    ));

Great for stats that previously needed multiple passes or mutable holders.

lessons.title: 300. PriorityBlockingQueue ordering
lessons.description: Insert numbers into a PriorityBlockingQueue and poll them to print 1, 2, 3 each on a new line.
lessons.tutorial:
A PriorityBlockingQueue orders elements by priority while supporting blocking producers/consumers.

Example:

PriorityBlockingQueue q = new PriorityBlockingQueue<>();
q.put(5);
q.put(2);
System.out.println(q.take()); // 2

Use it for work queues where higher-priority tasks must run first.

lessons.title: 301. Module Descriptor Summary
lessons.description: Summarize the key sections of a JPMS module descriptor in prose form.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Module Descriptor
Name: com.example.inventory
Requires: java.sql, com.fasterxml.jackson
Exports:
- com.example.inventory.api
- com.example.inventory.domain
Opens:
- com.example.inventory.config
Provides:
- com.example.spi.InventoryProvider -> com.example.inventory.internal.DbInventoryProvider
lessons.tutorial:
Listing exports, opens, and provides together gives reviewers quick confidence that the module boundary is intentional.

Reminder:

System.out.println("Provides:");

lessons.title: 302. Service Loader Wiring
lessons.description: Outline how a service interface maps to provider implementations and the configuration file that binds them.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Service Loader Wiring
Service: com.example.spi.InventoryProvider
Providers:
- com.example.inventory.DbProvider
- com.example.inventory.CacheProvider
Module hint: module com.example.inventory { provides com.example.spi.InventoryProvider with com.example.inventory.DbProvider, com.example.inventory.CacheProvider; }
Config file: META-INF/services/com.example.spi.InventoryProvider
lessons.tutorial:
Spell out both the module declaration and META-INF services file so runtime discovery never depends on tribal knowledge.

Pattern:

System.out.println("Providers:");

lessons.title: 303. Text Block HTML Template
lessons.description: Use a Java text block to hold a small HTML template and print it verbatim.
lessons.tutorial:
Text blocks preserve indentation and quotes, making embedded templates far easier to read.

Example:

String html = """...""";

lessons.title: 304. Switch Expression Routing
lessons.description: Route an environment name to a base URL using a switch expression and print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
Switch expressions remove fallthrough bugs and make routing tables readable.

Reminder:

String url = switch (env) { ... };

lessons.title: 305. Virtual Thread Launch Plan
lessons.description: Capture the rollout steps for adopting virtual threads in a service.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Virtual Thread Launch Plan
1. Enable --enable-preview in staging
2. Switch ExecutorService to newVirtualThreadPerTaskExecutor
3. Load test with 10x concurrency
4. Roll forward to production
lessons.tutorial:
Document the preview flag and load-testing expectations so migrations stay controlled.

Pattern:

for (int i = 0; i < steps.length; i++)

lessons.title: 306. jlink Image Checklist
lessons.description: Lay out the commands required to produce a trimmed runtime image with jlink.
lessons.expectedOutput:
jlink Image Checklist
1. Prepare: jdeps --multi-release 21 --print-module-deps --ignore-missing-deps app.jar
2. Assemble: jlink --add-modules com.example.inventory,java.sql --output build/image
3. Verify: build/image/bin/java -m com.example.inventory
lessons.tutorial:
Pair jdeps with jlink so runtime trimming stays reproducible from CI to prod.

Reminder:

System.out.println("jlink Image Checklist");

lessons.title: 307. ArrayDeque descendingIterator
lessons.description: Use ArrayDeque.descendingIterator() to report steps from newest to oldest.
lessons.tutorial:
ArrayDeque keeps insertion order and exposes descendingIterator() so you can walk the tail-first view without copying.

Example:

Iterator it = deque.descendingIterator();

lessons.title: 308. RandomGeneratorFactory Seeded Rollup
lessons.description: Create a deterministic L64X128MixRandom sequence and print the sum of three draws.
lessons.tutorial:
RandomGeneratorFactory lets you pick modern algorithms with explicit seeding for reproducible tests.

Example:

var rng = RandomGeneratorFactory.of("L64X128MixRandom").create(123);

lessons.title: 309. CompletableFuture.delayedExecutor
lessons.description: Complete a CompletableFuture via delayedExecutor and print the result.
lessons.tutorial:
Use delayedExecutor to inject latency without managing your own scheduler; it runs on ForkJoinPool.commonPool() by default.

Example:

CompletableFuture.delayedExecutor(50, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)

lessons.title: 310. ServerSocket echo
lessons.description: Start a local ServerSocket, uppercase the incoming message, and print the response from a client connection.
lessons.tutorial:
Pair ServerSocket with a background task so you can exercise request/response logic entirely in-process.

Pattern:

try (ServerSocket server = new ServerSocket(0)) {
    int port = server.getLocalPort();
    Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor().submit(server::accept);
}

lessons.title: 311. Properties load config
lessons.description: Load a configuration string with Properties and echo two keys.
lessons.tutorial:
Properties can parse configuration text straight from a string or Reader, making it easy to test configuration defaults.

Example:

Properties props = new Properties();
props.load(new StringReader(keyValues));

lessons.title: 312. ZipOutputStream in-memory
lessons.description: Create a zip archive in memory, reopen it, and list the entries.
lessons.tutorial:
Wrap a ZipOutputStream around a ByteArrayOutputStream when you need to stage release artifacts without touching disk. Reopen the bytes with ZipInputStream to inspect the contents.

Snippet:

try (ZipOutputStream zip = new ZipOutputStream(buffer)) {
    zip.putNextEntry(new ZipEntry(name));
}

lessons.title: 313. ObjectOutputStream round-trip
lessons.description: Serialize and deserialize a record to verify nested data survives the round-trip.
lessons.tutorial:
Java serialization is handy for quick state snapshots. Use ByteArrayOutputStream to keep tests self-contained, then deserialize with ObjectInputStream.

Example:

out.writeObject(profile);
Profile restored = (Profile) in.readObject();

lessons.title: 314. ClassLoader resource read
lessons.description: Create a classpath resource on the fly, load it with a URLClassLoader, and print its contents.
lessons.tutorial:
A throwaway URLClassLoader lets you simulate classpath resources in tests. Write the assets to a temp directory, load them, then tear everything down.

Pattern:

try (URLClassLoader loader = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] { dir.toUri().toURL() })) {
    loader.getResourceAsStream("assets/banner.txt");
}

lessons.title: 315. Map overrides merge
lessons.description: Merge overrides into defaults and print the resulting configuration values.
lessons.tutorial:
Combine defaults with environment-specific overrides by copying the base map and applying changes. The final map preserves insertion order for predictable diagnostics.

Example:

Map merged = new LinkedHashMap<>(defaults);
merged.putAll(overrides);

lessons.title: 316. Percentile (inclusive quartiles)
lessons.description: Compute the first and third quartiles using the inclusive method and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
Inclusive quartiles match the behavior of spreadsheets and Python's statistics module: interpolate between neighbors with h = (n - 1) * p + 1.

Snippet:

double h = (n - 1) * p + 1;
int lower = (int) Math.floor(h) - 1;

lessons.title: 317. HttpClient JSON Request
lessons.description: Build a Java 11+ HttpClient request with query parameters and JSON headers.
lessons.tutorial:
HttpRequest.newBuilder lets you compose the URI, timeout, and headers fluently before calling build(). The client can reuse the request instance.

Pattern:

HttpRequest.newBuilder()
    .uri(URI.create(url))
    .header("Accept", "application/json")
    .timeout(Duration.ofSeconds(2))
    .GET()
    .build();

lessons.title: 318. Pattern Matching Auth Records
lessons.description: Use instanceof pattern variables with a sealed hierarchy to classify authentication events.
lessons.tutorial:
Pattern matching for instanceof lets you bind the record components directly after the check, avoiding explicit casts.

Example:

if (event instanceof Failure failure) {
    if (failure.code() >= 500) {
        return "Permanent failure";
    }
}

lessons.title: 319. MessageDigest SHA-256 Fingerprint
lessons.description: Compute a SHA-256 digest and emit both the full hash and a short fingerprint.
lessons.tutorial:
MessageDigest provides streaming hashes. Use HexFormat.of().formatHex to avoid manual byte-to-hex loops.

Pattern:

MessageDigest md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-256");
String hex = HexFormat.of().formatHex(md.digest(bytes));

lessons.title: 320. invokeAny first success
lessons.description: Use ExecutorService.invokeAny to race primary and replica probes, printing whichever responds first.
lessons.tutorial:
invokeAny submits a batch of tasks and returns as soon as one completes successfully, cancelling the rest. It is a handy way to race redundant backends.

Pattern:

ExecutorService exec = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(n);
try {
    return exec.invokeAny(tasks);
} finally {
    exec.shutdownNow();
}

lessons.title: 321. ThreadLocal request context
lessons.description: Propagate a request id into tasks by setting and clearing a ThreadLocal inside each Callable.
lessons.tutorial:
Without ScopedValue or structured concurrency, you can still pass context by wrapping tasks that set a ThreadLocal before running and clear it afterward. This pattern keeps worker threads from leaking stale request data.

Pattern:

Callable wrapped = () -> {
    context.set(id);
    try {
        return task.call();
    } finally {
        context.remove();
    }
};

lessons.title: 322. ExecutorCompletionService first success
lessons.description: Race primary and replica callables using ExecutorCompletionService and print the first response.
lessons.tutorial:
ExecutorCompletionService wraps an ExecutorService and hands you completed futures in finishing order. Submit work with submit() and pull the earliest outcome with take().

Pattern:

ExecutorCompletionService ecs = new ExecutorCompletionService<>(executor);
ecs.submit(task);
Future winner = ecs.take();

Use this when you need first-completer semantics but also want direct access to the returned Future.

lessons.title: 323. CompletableFuture failure guard
lessons.description: Run inventory and analytics via CompletableFuture.allOf, printing a failure message when any task errors.
lessons.tutorial:
CompletableFuture.allOf propagates the first failure by wrapping it in a CompletionException. Surround the join with a try/catch to surface the underlying cause.

Pattern:

try {
    CompletableFuture.allOf(futures...).join();
} catch (CompletionException ex) {
    handle(ex.getCause());
}

After the join succeeds you can safely call join() on each individual future without re-checking for errors.

lessons.title: 324. CompletableFuture winner
lessons.description: Race two CompletableFutures and cancel the loser after retrieving the first result.
lessons.tutorial:
anyOf returns the first completed future without waiting for the rest, making it ideal for fallback strategies. Cast the Object back to the expected type when your futures share the same result type.

Pattern:

CompletableFuture

lessons.title: 325. Work-stealing invokeAll batch
lessons.description: Run blocking service calls on a work-stealing pool and print their results in submission order.
lessons.expectedOutput:
inventory done
pricing done
shipping done
lessons.tutorial:
Executors.newWorkStealingPool() creates a ForkJoinPool that dynamically balances blocking tasks across threads. invokeAll retains submission order even though work may hop between workers.

Pattern:

ExecutorService pool = Executors.newWorkStealingPool();
try {
    List> futures = pool.invokeAll(tasks);
    for (Future future : futures) {
        use(future.get());
    }
} finally {
    pool.shutdown();
}

Work-stealing keeps CPUs busy without manually sizing thread pools for mixed workloads.

lessons.title: 326. CompletableFuture timeout fallback
lessons.description: Apply orTimeout to a supplyAsync task and provide a fallback when the operation takes too long.
lessons.tutorial:
orTimeout injects a deadline into a CompletableFuture, completing it exceptionally with TimeoutException if it runs too long. Chain exceptionally to turn that failure into a clean fallback value.

Pattern:

CompletableFuture guarded = work
    .orTimeout(limit, unit)
    .exceptionally(ex -> fallback);

Pair this with retry loops or cached responses to keep latency predictable.

lessons.title: 327. CountDownLatch service rendezvous
lessons.description: Wait for several services to signal readiness with CountDownLatch before announcing that all are primed.
lessons.expectedOutput:
inventory primed
pricing primed
shipping primed
all services go
lessons.tutorial:
CountDownLatch lets you wait until a fixed number of signals arrive. Each worker decrements the latch, and the main thread blocks in await() until everyone checks in.

Pattern:

CountDownLatch latch = new CountDownLatch(n);
executor.submit(() -> {
    work();
    latch.countDown();
});
latch.await();

Use this for startup barriers or coordinated shutdown sequences.

lessons.title: 328. Semaphore concurrency gate
lessons.description: Cap parallel tasks with a Semaphore while gathering results in submission order.
lessons.expectedOutput:
alpha done
beta done
gamma done
lessons.tutorial:
Semaphores bound the number of concurrent entrants to a critical section. Acquire before starting work, release in a finally block, and everyone else waits their turn.

Pattern:

limiter.acquire();
try {
    doWork();
} finally {
    limiter.release();
}

Combine with invokeAll to preserve submission order while still limiting resource pressure.

lessons.title: 329. CompletableFuture handle outcome
lessons.description: Use CompletableFuture.handle to turn either a successful value or an exception into a status string.
lessons.tutorial:
handle receives both the value and the exception (if any) from the upstream stage, letting you fold everything into a single continuation.

Pattern:

future.handle((value, ex) -> ex == null ? success(value) : recover(ex))

Remember to unwrap CompletionException when mapping failures from asynchronous stages.

lessons.title: 330. Phaser barrier release
lessons.description: Coordinate multiple services through Phaser so they all wait for a gate to open before proceeding.
lessons.expectedOutput:
pricing prepped
shipping prepped
inventory prepped
gate open
pricing go
shipping go
inventory go
lessons.tutorial:
Phaser coordinates batches of parties across phases. Register each participant, let them "arrive" when they finish pre-work, and wait for the phase to advance before continuing.

Pattern:

phaser.register();
// prep work
phaser.arriveAndAwaitAdvance();
// synchronized release
phaser.arriveAndDeregister();

Choose delays or additional coordination if you need deterministic post-barrier ordering for demonstrations.

lessons.title: 331. ReentrantReadWriteLock snapshot
lessons.description: Guard configuration updates with a ReentrantReadWriteLock so readers see the latest snapshot once the writer commits.
lessons.expectedOutput:
alpha reads enabled
beta reads enabled
lessons.tutorial:
Writers take the exclusive lock while readers share the read lock. By waiting for the writer to hold the lock before launching readers, you ensure they block until the update is committed and then observe the fresh snapshot.

Pattern:

lock.writeLock().lock();
try {
    update();
} finally {
    lock.writeLock().unlock();
}

lock.readLock().lock();
try {
    use();
} finally {
    lock.readLock().unlock();
}

lessons.title: 332. CompletableFuture thenCompose chain
lessons.description: Compose two asynchronous stages so the second depends on the result of the first.
lessons.tutorial:
Use thenCompose when a stage returns another CompletableFuture. It flattens the futures so you can treat the downstream result as a single asynchronous pipeline.

Pattern:

future.thenCompose(this::nextAsync)

Compare with thenApply, which would leave you with a nested completion stage.

lessons.title: 333. ScheduledExecutor fixed rate
lessons.description: Schedule a repeating heartbeat with ScheduledExecutorService.scheduleAtFixedRate and stop after three ticks.
lessons.tutorial:
scheduleAtFixedRate launches tasks with a fixed period between start times. Use an AtomicInteger to count iterations and call shutdown() when done.

Pattern:

scheduler.scheduleAtFixedRate(task, initialDelay, period, unit);

Always shut down the scheduler to release the thread.

lessons.title: 334. StampedLock optimistic read
lessons.description: Use StampedLock to take an optimistic read snapshot and fall back to the read lock if contention occurs.
lessons.tutorial:
StampedLock allows optimistic reads that avoid locking when no writer interferes. Validate the stamp; if it has been invalidated by a write, fall back to a read lock.

Pattern:

long stamp = lock.tryOptimisticRead();
T value = snapshot();
if (!lock.validate(stamp)) {
    stamp = lock.readLock();
    try {
        value = snapshot();
    } finally {
        lock.unlockRead(stamp);
    }
}

Optimistic reads shine when writers are rare and you want minimal reader contention.

lessons.title: 335. Collectors.filtering critical services
lessons.description: Group services by audience and use Collectors.filtering to keep only critical names per bucket.
lessons.tutorial:
Collectors.filtering lets you drop elements inside a downstream collector without rewriting the surrounding pipeline. Pair it with groupingBy to keep each segment focused.

Pattern:

Map view = items.stream()
    .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(keyFn,
        Collectors.filtering(predicate, downstream)));

Filter inside the collector when you still need the original element for other aggregations.

lessons.title: 336. TemporalAdjusters sprint milestones
lessons.description: Use TemporalAdjusters to snap a date to the sprint start, find the next Friday retro, and the month-end release.
lessons.tutorial:
TemporalAdjusters snap a LocalDate to calendar boundaries such as first/last days or relative weekdays.

Pattern:

LocalDate start = date.with(TemporalAdjusters.previousOrSame(DayOfWeek.MONDAY));
LocalDate retro = start.plusWeeks(2).with(TemporalAdjusters.next(DayOfWeek.FRIDAY));

Mix adjusters to build sprint schedules, billing cycles, or reporting windows without manual arithmetic.

lessons.title: 337. Stream.takeWhile latency window
lessons.description: Use Stream.takeWhile to keep low-latency samples and print them as a comma-separated list.
lessons.tutorial:
Stream.takeWhile keeps consuming elements while the predicate holds, stopping as soon as the first failure appears. This is perfect for sorted metrics where everything after the first slow value is suspect.

Pattern:

stream.takeWhile(predicate).map(...).collect(joining(", "))

Because the stream short-circuits, you avoid scanning the rest of the data once a threshold is breached.

lessons.title: 338. Files.mismatch diff peek
lessons.description: Detect the first differing byte between two build artifacts with Files.mismatch.
lessons.tutorial:
Files.mismatch(Path, Path) (Java 12+) returns the first differing byte position or -1 when files are identical, giving you a fast health check for generated artifacts.

Pattern:

long diff = Files.mismatch(a, b);
if (diff == -1) {
    System.out.println("match");
}

Wrap comparisons in try/finally so temporary fixtures are cleaned even if the comparison raises.

lessons.title: 339. Stream.dropWhile incident tail
lessons.description: Use Stream.dropWhile to skip healthy entries and print the remaining alerts.
lessons.tutorial:
Stream.dropWhile continues removing elements while the predicate is true, then yields the rest unchanged. Pair it with dropWhile to ignore the calm before the incident and focus on the tail of warnings.

Pattern:

var tail = list.stream().dropWhile(predicate).collect(joining(", "));

Unlike filter, dropWhile only trims the front of the stream, preserving later entries even if they match the predicate.

lessons.title: 340. Map.copyOf defensive snapshot
lessons.description: Create an unmodifiable copy of configuration overrides with Map.copyOf and confirm it is immutable.
lessons.tutorial:
Map.copyOf creates an unmodifiable snapshot of the input map, ideal for freezing configuration before handing it to other threads.

Pattern:

Map snapshot = Map.copyOf(source);

Subsequent mutations to the original map do not affect the snapshot, and write attempts on the snapshot raise UnsupportedOperationException.

lessons.title: 341. Stream.iterate capacity ramp
lessons.description: Generate doubling capacity steps with the three-argument Stream.iterate overload and print them in order.
lessons.tutorial:
The Java 9 Stream.iterate(seed, predicate, next) overload generates finite sequences without extra takeWhile/filter calls. Here we double capacity until hitting the threshold.

Pattern:

Stream.iterate(seed, predicate, next)

Use this form whenever you have a deterministic termination condition to keep streams declarative.

lessons.title: 342. LocalDate.datesUntil sprint cadence
lessons.description: List weekly sprint review dates using LocalDate.datesUntil with a Period step.
lessons.tutorial:
LocalDate.datesUntil(endExclusive, step) walks a range of dates with the granularity you choose. Stepping by a weekly Period keeps recurring ceremonies aligned.

Pattern:

start.datesUntil(end, Period.ofWeeks(1))

Choose endExclusive as the first date you want to exclude so the range remains intuitive.

lessons.title: 343. Median latency snapshot
lessons.description: Sort latency samples and compute the median as a double, then print it.
lessons.tutorial:
Clone the data into a mutable list, sort it, and average the middle values when the count is even.

Pattern:

Collections.sort(samples);
int left = count / 2 - 1;
double median = (samples.get(left) + samples.get(left + 1)) / 2.0;

Use medians to report typical latency when outliers make the mean jump around.

lessons.title: 344. Linear regression forecast
lessons.description: Run a least-squares linear regression on quarterly signups and project the next quarter.
lessons.tutorial:
Compute the mean of x and y, sum (x-meanX)*(y-meanY), and divide by the sum of squared x deltas to get the slope.

Pattern:

double slope = num / den;
double intercept = meanY - slope * meanX;

With slope and intercept, you can forecast workloads or revenue by plugging in the next index.

lessons.title: 345. Jar deployment bundle
lessons.description: Assemble a tiny deployment jar with a manifest and resource file, then inspect its entries.
lessons.tutorial:
JarOutputStream writes the manifest and entries into a standard zip archive that the JVM understands.

Pattern:

new JarOutputStream(Files.newOutputStream(path), manifest)

Reopen the jar with FileSystems.newFileSystem to spot-check contents during packaging steps or CI checks.

lessons.title: 346. DoubleSummaryStatistics throughput
lessons.description: Gather count, min, average, and max latency using DoubleSummaryStatistics and print a formatted summary.
lessons.tutorial:
DoubleSummaryStatistics collects count, min, max, sum, and average in a single pass, perfect for latency or throughput dashboards.

Pattern:

DoubleSummaryStatistics stats = values.stream()\n    .mapToDouble(Double::doubleValue)\n    .summaryStatistics();

Format the numbers to the precision your SLO dashboards expect before printing.

lessons.title: 347. Reflection deprecated audit
lessons.description: Use reflection to list methods annotated with @Deprecated and report their version metadata.
lessons.tutorial:
Reflection lets you turn annotations into runtime metadata so you can build audits and tooling without hand-maintaining allowlists.

Pattern:

Arrays.stream(type.getDeclaredMethods())\n    .filter(m -> m.isAnnotationPresent(Deprecated.class))

Sort the results for deterministic output, especially when feeding reports into CI pipelines.

lessons.title: 348. ZipOutputStream static bundle
lessons.description: Package a static site directory into a zip archive with ZipOutputStream and list its entries.
lessons.tutorial:
ZipOutputStream lets you build deployment bundles without calling external tools, keeping CI steps portable.

Pattern:

try (ZipOutputStream zip = new ZipOutputStream(out)) {
    Files.walk(root)
        .filter(Files::isRegularFile)
        .forEach(path -> zip.putNextEntry(new ZipEntry(...)));
}

Normalize separators to '/' so archives look the same on every platform.

lessons.title: 349. Class-based router
lessons.description: Route payloads by their runtime class using a handler map and print formatted messages.
lessons.tutorial:
Mapping runtime classes to handlers mirrors Python's singledispatchmethod: one entry point, multiple type-aware implementations.

Pattern:

handlers.put(Type.class, payload -> { /* format and emit */ });

Throw on unsupported types so missing registrations fail loudly during tests.

lessons.title: 350. Geometric mean growth
lessons.description: Compute the geometric mean of growth factors with streams and report the compounded percentage.
lessons.tutorial:
Reduce the factors into a product, then raise it to 1/n to capture compounded growth without letting outliers dominate.

Pattern:

double product = stream.reduce(1.0, (a, b) -> a * b);
double mean = Math.pow(product, 1.0 / n);

Translate the multiplier back to a percentage so stakeholders can read the result at a glance.

lessons.title: 351. VarHandle atomic counter
lessons.description: Use VarHandle to atomically initialize and increment a counter field, then print the final value.
lessons.tutorial:
VarHandle offers lock-free access to fields and array elements. Locate the handle once, then use operations such as getAndAdd to perform atomic arithmetic.

Pattern:

VarHandle h = MethodHandles.lookup().findVarHandle(Type.class, "field", int.class);
h.getAndAdd(obj, 1);
int value = (int) h.getVolatile(obj);

VarHandles reduce the need for AtomicInteger wrappers when you want field-level atomics.

lessons.title: 352. Flow publisher subscriber
lessons.description: Wire a SubmissionPublisher to a Flow.Subscriber, capture events, and print them in order.
lessons.tutorial:
SubmissionPublisher implements the Reactive Streams Flow.Publisher API. Request demand in onSubscribe, process events in onNext, and close resources in onComplete.

Pattern:

publisher.subscribe(subscriber);
publisher.submit(data);
publisher.close();
latched.await();

Latch the completion signal to keep the JVM alive until the asynchronous publisher finishes delivering items.

lessons.title: 353. Cleaner resource finalizer
lessons.description: Register a resource with java.lang.ref.Cleaner so closing it triggers deterministic cleanup output.
lessons.tutorial:
Use Cleaner to register cleanup tasks that run when a resource is closed or garbage collected. Calling clean() executes the action immediately and deregisters it.

Pattern:

Cleaner cleaner = Cleaner.create();
Cleaner.Cleanable cleanable = cleaner.register(obj, () -> release());
cleanable.clean();

Pair Cleaner with try-with-resources so cleanup runs deterministically, while still safeguarding against leaked handles.

lessons.title: 354. LinkedTransferQueue handoff
lessons.description: Coordinate a producer and consumer with LinkedTransferQueue.transfer and print the received items.
lessons.tutorial:
LinkedTransferQueue combines the best of queues and synchronous handoff channels. transfer blocks until a consumer receives the element, making it ideal for throttled pipelines.

Pattern:

queue.transfer(task);
String item = queue.take();

Because transfer waits for a taker, producers and consumers stay in lock-step without extra signaling.

lessons.title: 355. StackWalker method trace
lessons.description: Use StackWalker to capture the top of the call stack and print the method chain.
lessons.tutorial:
StackWalker gives you structured access to stack frames without parsing exception text. Limit the walk to just the frames you care about.

Pattern:

String trace = StackWalker.getInstance().walk(frames -> frames
    .map(StackWalker.StackFrame::getMethodName)
    .limit(3)
    .collect(Collectors.joining("->")));
System.out.println(trace);

Use it for diagnostics or structured logging instead of brittle stack trace strings.

lessons.title: 356. WatchService create event
lessons.description: Watch a temporary directory for file creation and print the resulting event.
lessons.tutorial:
WatchService lets you react to filesystem changes without polling. Register the directory once, then block on watch.take() for incoming events.

Pattern:

dir.register(watch, StandardWatchEventKinds.ENTRY_CREATE);
Files.writeString(file, "data");
boolean printed = false;
while (!printed) {
    WatchKey key = watch.take();
    for (WatchEvent<?> event : key.pollEvents()) {
        if (event.kind() == StandardWatchEventKinds.OVERFLOW) continue;
        if (event.kind() == StandardWatchEventKinds.ENTRY_CREATE) {
            Path name = (Path) event.context();
            System.out.println(event.kind().name() + ":" + name);
            printed = true;
            break;
        }
    }
    key.reset();
}

Always delete temporary fixtures and ignore OVERFLOW signals so bursts of activity do not break your pipeline.

lessons.title: 357. MethodHandle private invocation
lessons.description: Invoke a private instance method via MethodHandle and print the greeting.
lessons.tutorial:
Method handles are typed, directly executable references to class members. Resolve them once, then invoke without reflection strings.

Pattern:

MethodHandle mh = MethodHandles.lookup().findVirtual(
    Greeter.class,
    "greet",
    MethodType.methodType(String.class, String.class)
);
String msg = (String) mh.invokeExact(instance, "team");

They underpin lambdas and give you faster, safer reflective access compared to Method.invoke.

lessons.title: 358. FileChannel transferTo stream
lessons.description: Copy a file into memory using FileChannel.transferTo and print the captured text.
lessons.tutorial:
FileChannel.transferTo streams bytes directly between channels, avoiding manual ByteBuffer loops.

Pattern:

long position = 0;
long size = channel.size();
while (position < size) {
    position += channel.transferTo(position, size - position, sink);
}

Always wrap temp files with try/finally so you clean them even if copying fails.

lessons.title: 359. Normalizer accent stripping
lessons.description: Normalize an accented label to ASCII by removing combining marks and building a lowercase slug.
lessons.tutorial:
Normalizer.Form.NFD splits characters into base letters plus combining marks. Filter out the non-spacing marks to collapse accents before lowercasing.

Pattern:

String clean = Normalizer.normalize(text, Normalizer.Form.NFD)
    .codePoints()
    .filter(cp -> Character.getType(cp) != Character.NON_SPACING_MARK)
    .collect(StringBuilder::new, StringBuilder::appendCodePoint, StringBuilder::append)
    .toString();

This is a lightweight way to generate ASCII slugs without external libraries.

lessons.title: 360. ConcurrentSkipListMap priority queue
lessons.description: Use ConcurrentSkipListMap to maintain a sorted backlog, remove the highest-priority item, and print the remaining order.
lessons.tutorial:
ConcurrentSkipListMap keeps keys in sorted order while remaining thread-safe, so you can treat it like a concurrent priority queue keyed by integers.

Pattern:

ConcurrentSkipListMap queue = new ConcurrentSkipListMap<>();
queue.put(priority, task);
var head = queue.pollFirstEntry();
process(head.getValue());

Its lock-free skip list keeps reads fast even when multiple producers are adding work.

lessons.title: 361. RecordComponent introspection
lessons.description: Reflect over a record's components and print their names with simple types.
lessons.tutorial:
Records expose their components via reflection, so you can build serializers or inspectors without hand-maintaining field lists.

Pattern:

RecordComponent[] components = recordType.getRecordComponents();
for (RecordComponent rc : components) {
    System.out.println(rc.getName());
}

Each component exposes the accessor method, type, and annotations, making runtime tooling ergonomic.

lessons.title: 362. Switch pattern matching guards
lessons.description: Use a switch expression with pattern matching and guards to format different payload variants.
lessons.tutorial:
Switch expressions can destructure records and add guard clauses. Use when to refine a matched pattern without another case.

Pattern:

return switch (payload) {
    case NumberPayload(int value) when value > 99 -> "large";
    case NumberPayload(int value) -> "small:" + value;
    case FlagPayload(boolean enabled) -> enabled ? "on" : "off";
};

Remember to cover every sealed subtype or provide a default branch so the compiler sees an exhaustive switch.

lessons.title: 363. Virtual thread executor fan-out
lessons.description: Fan out work onto a virtual-thread-backed executor, await the futures in submission order, and print their results as a single line.
lessons.tutorial:
Virtual threads let you schedule thousands of blocking tasks without the overhead of platform threads. The new-per-task executor wires each task to its own virtual thread.

Pattern:

try (ExecutorService executor = Executors.newVirtualThreadPerTaskExecutor()) {
    Future future = executor.submit(() -> {
        TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.sleep(10);
        return "ready";
    });
    System.out.println(future.get());
}

Gathering futures in submission order makes it easy to preserve deterministic output even though the tasks complete out of order.

lessons.title: 364. VarHandle compare-and-set loop
lessons.description: Acquire a VarHandle for an int array element, atomically add to it with a compare-and-set loop, and print the updated value.
lessons.tutorial:
VarHandle gives you low-level atomic operations without dropping into unsafe APIs. Loop on compareAndSet until you win the race, then read the updated value.

Pattern:

VarHandle handle = MethodHandles.arrayElementVarHandle(int[].class);
int value;
do {
    value = (int) handle.getVolatile(array, index);
} while (!handle.compareAndSet(array, index, value, value + delta));

The volatile access keeps other threads from caching stale values, making this a safe lock-free increment.

lessons.title: 365. StructuredTaskScope coordination
lessons.description: Run two blocking operations inside a StructuredTaskScope, wait for completion, and print their combined result.
lessons.tutorial:
Structured concurrency scopes let you launch related subtasks and coordinate their lifetime. ShutdownOnFailure cancels sibling work if any fork fails.

Pattern:

try (var scope = new StructuredTaskScope.ShutdownOnFailure()) {
    var a = scope.fork(this::loadA);
    var b = scope.fork(this::loadB);
    scope.join();
    scope.throwIfFailed();
    return combine(a.get(), b.get());
}

Always call join() followed by throwIfFailed() so exceptions surface before you use the subtasks' results.

lessons.title: 366. SequencedSet rotation
lessons.description: Take advantage of SequencedSet methods to move the last element to the front and print the new ordering.
lessons.tutorial:
Sequenced collections expose first/last operations directly, removing the need to bounce through iterators when you want to rotate data.

Pattern:

SequencedSet set = new LinkedHashSet<>(List.of("a", "b", "c"));
String tail = set.removeLast();
set.addFirst(tail);
System.out.println(String.join(",", set));

LinkedHashSet already preserves insertion order, and with SequencedSet you can manipulate both ends in O(1).

lessons.title: 367. Collectors teeing summary
lessons.description: Use Collectors.teeing to compute both the average and maximum score in a single terminal operation.
lessons.tutorial:
Collectors.teeing lets you fan out a stream into two downstream collectors and merge their results in one pass, saving extra traversals.

Pattern:

String report = data.stream().collect(Collectors.teeing(
    Collectors.counting(),
    Collectors.maxBy(Comparator.naturalOrder()),
    (count, max) -> "count=" + count + ",max=" + max.orElse(0)
));

Combine averaging, counting, or grouping collectors to build rich summaries without intermediate collections.

lessons.title: 368. CompletableFuture anyOf race
lessons.description: Start two asynchronous tasks, print whichever completes first with CompletableFuture.anyOf, then print both results.
lessons.tutorial:
Use CompletableFuture.anyOf when you only need the first result from a set of asynchronous computations. The returned future completes as soon as any input does.

Pattern:

CompletableFuture<?> first = CompletableFuture.anyOf(a, b, c);
Object value = first.join();

You can still use the original futures afterwardhere we join them explicitly to force completion and reuse their values.

lessons.title: 369. Files.walk log size
lessons.description: Create a temporary tree of log files, sum the sizes of all .log entries with Files.walk, print the total, and clean up the directory.
lessons.tutorial:
Files.walk streams every path under a directory. Filter to the files you care about, then map to their sizes for aggregation.

Pattern:

try (Stream<Path> paths = Files.walk(root)) {
    long bytes = paths
        .filter(Files::isRegularFile)
        .filter(p -> p.toString().endsWith(".log"))
        .mapToLong(Main::size)
        .sum();
}

Always remember to clean up temporary treessorting the walk in reverse order lets you delete children before parents.

lessons.title: 370. Base64 round-trip
lessons.description: Encode text to Base64 and decode it back using java.util.Base64, printing both forms.
lessons.tutorial:
Base64 lets you ship binary data over text protocols. Java exposes encoders and decoders directly on Base64.

Pattern:

String encoded = Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString(bytes);
byte[] decoded = Base64.getDecoder().decode(encoded);

Always specify the charset when turning strings into bytes so you get a stable round-trip across platforms.

lessons.title: 371. ByteBuffer little-endian decode
lessons.description: Interpret a little-endian byte buffer as two 32-bit integers and print them.
lessons.tutorial:
ByteBuffer defaults to big-endian. Switch to little-endian before reading if the source data uses reverse byte order.

Pattern:

ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.wrap(bytes).order(ByteOrder.LITTLE_ENDIAN);
int value = buffer.getInt();

Once you read an int, the buffer position advances, so sequential getInt() calls walk the structure field by field.

lessons.title: 372. HmacSHA256 signature
lessons.description: Compute an HMAC-SHA256 signature for a message, print the full hex digest, then print the first 12 characters.
lessons.tutorial:
HMAC provides integrity for messages using a shared secret. Initialize Mac with a SecretKeySpec and feed it the payload bytes.

Pattern:

Mac mac = Mac.getInstance("HmacSHA256");
mac.init(new SecretKeySpec(keyBytes, "HmacSHA256"));
byte[] digest = mac.doFinal(messageBytes);

Use HexFormat to render the signature without manual byte formatting.

lessons.title: 373. GZIP compress round-trip
lessons.description: GZIP-compress a string into memory, print the compressed byte length, then decompress and print the original text.
lessons.tutorial:
Wrap byte streams with GZIPOutputStream and GZIPInputStream to compress data in-memory. Call finish() before grabbing the bytes so the footer is flushed.

Pattern:

try (GZIPOutputStream gzip = new GZIPOutputStream(out)) {
    gzip.write(bytes);
}
try (GZIPInputStream gin = new GZIPInputStream(new ByteArrayInputStream(out.toByteArray()))) {
    gin.readAllBytes();
}

This mirrors how you would stage responses before uploading them to object storage or sending over the network.

lessons.title: 374. Duration between Instants
lessons.description: Parse two ISO-8601 timestamps, compute the duration between them, and print the milliseconds.
lessons.tutorial:
Instant.parse handles RFC 3339 timestamps. Duration.between gives you the elapsed time, which you can convert to milliseconds for logging or metrics.

Pattern:

Instant start = Instant.parse(startIso);
Instant end = Instant.parse(endIso);
long millis = Duration.between(start, end).toMillis();

Always watch out for timezone offsetsInstants stay in UTC so math stays straightforward.

lessons.title: 375. Map.merge word counts
lessons.description: Use Map.merge to count word occurrences from an array and print the counts in insertion order.
lessons.tutorial:
Map.merge inserts a value when missing or combines with the existing entry via a remapping function. Use it to avoid explicit containsKey checks.

Pattern:

counts.merge(word, 1, Integer::sum);

A LinkedHashMap keeps insertion order, so you can replay the tallied counts in the order words first appeared.

lessons.title: 376. HttpRequest builder with timeout and headers
lessons.description: Build an HttpRequest with query parameters, a timeout, and headers, then print its details.
lessons.tutorial:
Pattern-build requests: set the target URI, configure timeouts, and attach headers before calling build(). HttpRequest instances are immutable, so you can reuse them safely.

Pattern:

HttpRequest.newBuilder()
    .uri(URI.create(url))
    .timeout(Duration.ofSeconds(2))
    .header("Accept", "application/json")
    .GET()
    .build();

Query parameters belong in the URI; using String.format or URI builders helps avoid typo-prone concatenation in real projects.
